courses.title: Intro.Cmpt.Sci/Programming I
courses.document:
CMPT 120 - Intro.Cmpt.Sci/Programming I
Department: CMPT | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby, Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q, B-Sci | Prerequisites: None

An elementary introduction to computing science and computer programming, suitable for students with little or no programming background. Students will learn fundamental concepts and terminology of computing science, acquire elementary skills for programming in a high-level language, e.g. Python. The students will be exposed to diverse fields within, and applications of computing science. Topics will include: pseudocode; data types and control structures; fundamental algorithms; recursion; reading and writing files; measuring performance of algorithms; debugging tools; basic terminal navigation using shell commands. Treatment is informal and programming is presented as a problem-solving tool.

Good for students interested in: computing science, programming fundamentals, python programming, algorithms, recursion, file handling, control structures, debugging techniques

metadata.prerequisites_raw: BC Math 12 or equivalent is recommended.

courses.title: Selected Questions and Issues
courses.document:
EDUC 100W - Selected Questions and Issues
Department: EDUC | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online, In Person
WQB: W, B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

An introduction to a small but representative sample of basic questions and issues in education. Students will examine questions relating to: the concept or idea of education; learning and the learner; teaching and the teacher; and more generally, the broader contexts of education. This course also introduces students to different ways of exploring educational questions and issues from philosophical and critical analysis, to historical and cross-cultural studies, to empirical research. Cannot be taken for credit by students with credit for 300 and 400 level education courses.

Good for students interested in: education theory, learning theories, teaching methods, educational philosophy, critical analysis, historical perspectives in education, cross-cultural education, empirical research methods

courses.title: Literature Now
courses.document:
ENGL 112W - Literature Now
Department: ENGL | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: W, B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Introduces students to contemporary works of literature in English and/or contemporary approaches to interpreting literature. May focus on one or multiple genres. Includes attention to writing skills.

Good for students interested in: contemporary literature, literary analysis, genre studies, critical thinking, writing skills, interpretation methods, modern literary theory

courses.title: Language and Purpose
courses.document:
ENGL 114W - Language and Purpose
Department: ENGL | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: W, B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Introduces students to the relationships between writing and purpose, between the features of texts and their meaning and effects. May focus on one or more literary or non-literary genres, including (but not limited to) essays, oratory, autobiography, poetry, and journalism. Includes attention to writing skills.

Good for students interested in: rhetorical analysis, writing skills, literary genres, non-literary genres, text interpretation, persuasive writing, critical reading, composition techniques

courses.title: Knowledge and Reality
courses.document:
PHIL 100W - Knowledge and Reality
Department: PHIL | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: W, B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

An introduction to some of the central problems of philosophy. Topics to be discussed include the different theories of reality; the nature and sources of knowledge, truth, evidence, and reason; the justification of belief and knowledge about the universe. These topics and problems will be considered as they arise in the context of issues such as: relativism versus absolutism; the existence of God; personal identity; the nature of the mind and its relation to the body; free will and determinism; the possibility of moral knowledge. Open to all students.

Good for students interested in: epistemology, metaphysics, theories of reality, justification of belief, truth and evidence, personal identity, free will and determinism, critical thinking

courses.title: Moral and Legal Problems
courses.document:
PHIL 120W - Moral and Legal Problems
Department: PHIL | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: W, B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

A critical examination of a range of moral and legal issues we confront in our dealings with the state and our fellow human beings, such as: Is it wrong to break the law? Should pornography and recreational drugs be illegal? Do animals have rights? Is there a duty to admit immigrants? Are there duties to the world's poor? Are indigenous peoples owed reparations?

Good for students interested in: moral philosophy, legal ethics, human rights, social justice, critical reasoning, ethical dilemmas, public policy, normative ethics

courses.title: Statistics in Everyday Life
courses.document:
STAT 100 - Statistics in Everyday Life
Department: STAT | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q, B-Sci | Prerequisites: None

Should you trust media reports on statistics about climate change or the spread of a virus? How do advertisers use statistics to influence our thinking? Explore statistics in real-world applications (opinion polls, sports, lotteries, and investments). Designed for students from all backgrounds, with a focus on concepts, not technical calculations.

Good for students interested in: statistics, data interpretation, probability, critical thinking, real-world applications, media literacy, opinion polls, decision making

courses.title: Classical Mythology
courses.document:
HUM 102W - Classical Mythology
Department: HUM | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: W, B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Introduction to the central myths and literary sources of the ancient Greeks and Romans. The course investigates the nature, function, and meaning of myths in the classical world.

Good for students interested in: classical mythology, ancient greek myths, roman mythology, literary analysis, myth interpretation, cultural symbolism, narrative structures, critical thinking

courses.title: 3D Printing Technologies
courses.document:
TEKX 101 - 3D Printing Technologies
Department: TEKX | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q, B-Sci | Prerequisites: None

Provides the background and skill set to use 3D printer and laser scanning technologies, and will be done in cooperation with the Maker Space initiative at the SFU Library. Students will learn the basic concepts of 3D printing, computer design tools, and the use of 3D scanners to make replicas of existing objects. Students will complete several 3D printed projects within the course.

Good for students interested in: 3d printing, laser scanning, computer-aided design, 3d scanners, rapid prototyping, digital fabrication, additive manufacturing, project-based learning

courses.title: Early World Literatures
courses.document:
WL 103W - Early World Literatures
Department: WL | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: W, B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Introduces ways of comparing early world literatures across time and space. May explore fundamental themes such as love, heroism, or the underworld.

Good for students interested in: comparative literature, early world literatures, thematic analysis, literary themes, cross-cultural studies, narrative structures, mythological motifs, critical reading

courses.title: Human Nutrition
courses.document:
BPK 110 - Human Nutrition
Department: BPK | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online, In Person
WQB: B-Sci | Prerequisites: None

An introduction of the principles of human nutrition with an emphasis on topics of current interest. The material is presented in a Canadian context to focus on nutrition practices and problems in this country. Students will gain an understanding of factors affecting food selection and the role of nutrition in maintaining good health. Students will develop the ability to discriminate between reliable and unreliable information on the subject of food and nutrition.

Good for students interested in: human nutrition, dietary guidelines, food selection, nutrition and health, nutrition assessment, critical evaluation of nutrition information, canadian nutrition practices, nutrition principles

courses.title: Contemporary Health
courses.document:
BPK 140 - Contemporary Health
Department: BPK | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online, In Person
WQB: B-Sci | Prerequisites: None

Explores health from a holistic perspective, in which health is viewed as physical, psychological, and social well-being. Considers genetics, environment, personal health behaviors (such as diet, exercise, stress management, and drug use), socioeconomic status, health care delivery systems, and aging with the intent to improve students' abilities to evaluate health information.

Good for students interested in: holistic health, physical well-being, psychological health, social determinants of health, health behaviors, health care systems, aging, health information evaluation

courses.title: Intro to Indigenous Studies
courses.document:
INDG 101 - Intro to Indigenous Studies
Department: INDG | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online, In Person
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Introduces the nature and goals of Indigenous Studies as an academic discipline that emphasizes cultures and homelands of First Peoples.

Good for students interested in: indigenous cultures, indigenous histories, cultural preservation, land rights, decolonization, indigenous epistemologies, community engagement, critical analysis

courses.title: Indigenous Perspective on Hist
courses.document:
INDG 201W - Indigenous Perspective on Hist
Department: INDG | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: W, B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

An examination of fact and ideology in history and historic events involving contact between Indigenous and European peoples. The course will also address questions of research methodologies in studying Indigenous/European relations, such as the evaluation of oral history and written ethnohistoric sources. An additional focus will be on gender as it influences perspectives.

Good for students interested in: indigenous history, european contact, oral history, ethnohistory, research methodologies, gender perspectives, historical analysis, indigenous-european relations

courses.title: Intro to Sociology
courses.document:
SA 150 - Intro to Sociology
Department: SA | Level: 100 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online, In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

Explores how sociologists study, describe, and explain social life. Introduces the sociological perspective and applies it to fundamental social process and everyday issues. As we consider phenomena ranging from interactions among individuals to societal and global inequalities, students critically examine social issues to build their understanding of the world.

Good for students interested in: sociological perspective, social processes, social inequalities, social interactions, critical thinking, social analysis, everyday social issues

courses.title: Anc. People/Places
courses.document:
ARCH 100 - Anc. People/Places
Department: ARCH | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

A broad survey of human cultural development from the late Palaeolithic/PalaeoIndian periods (ca 40,000 BP) to the rise of civilization and empires, in both the Old and New Worlds.

Good for students interested in: human cultural development, late palaeolithic, palaeoindian periods, rise of civilization, ancient empires, archaeology, prehistoric societies, cultural anthropology

courses.title: Reconstructing the Human Past
courses.document:
ARCH 101 - Reconstructing the Human Past
Department: ARCH | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

A survey of methods used by archaeologists to discover and interpret the past. Examples will be drawn from selected sites and cultures around the world.

Good for students interested in: archaeological methods, cultural interpretation, excavation techniques, artifact analysis, site surveying, human history, cultural heritage, research methodologies

courses.title: Human Origins
courses.document:
ARCH 131 - Human Origins
Department: ARCH | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

A non-technical survey of the primate background of humans, fossil primates, and fossil humans, and the associated evidence of cultural development. An introduction to physical anthropology.

Good for students interested in: physical anthropology, primate evolution, fossil analysis, human origins, cultural development, evolutionary biology, paleoanthropology, comparative anatomy

courses.title: Introduction to Cinema
courses.document:
CA 135 - Introduction to Cinema
Department: CA | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Introduces students to the techniques, styles and forms of cinema in order to develop the skills with which to analyze films of all genres. Through lectures and screenings, it will provide an overview of the social, aesthetic and technical development of motion pictures, introducing tools for the formal analysis of the elements of cinema: cinematography and lighting, art direction, performance, editing, sound and the screenplay.

Good for students interested in: cinematography, film analysis, editing techniques, sound design, art direction, screenplay structure, film history, visual storytelling

courses.title: Sound
courses.document:
CA 149 - Sound
Department: CA | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: None

Introduction to acoustics, psychoacoustics, sound synthesis, audio sampling and signal processing, and sound production in general as relating to music, film sound, radio, new media, art installations and live performance.

Good for students interested in: acoustics, psychoacoustics, sound synthesis, audio sampling, signal processing, sound production, music technology, audio engineering

courses.title: General Chem/Lab I
courses.document:
CHEM 121 - General Chem/Lab I
Department: CHEM | Level: 100 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q, B-Sci | Prerequisites: Chemistry 12 with a minimum grade of B, or CHEM 109 or 111 with a minimum grade of C- or CHEM 110 and 115, both with a minimum grade of C-.

Atomic and molecular structure; chemical bonding; thermochemistry; elements; periodic table; gases, liquids, solids, and solutions. This course includes a laboratory component.

Good for students interested in: atomic structure, molecular structure, chemical bonding, thermochemistry, periodic table, states of matter, solutions, laboratory techniques

metadata.prerequisites_raw: Chemistry 12 with a minimum grade of B, or CHEM 109 or 111 with a minimum grade of C- or CHEM 110 and 115, both with a minimum grade of C-.

courses.title: Intro Cmns Studies
courses.document:
CMNS 110 - Intro Cmns Studies
Department: CMNS | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

An introduction to selected theories about human communication. This course is required for a major, honours or minor in communication.

Good for students interested in: human communication, communication theories, interpersonal communication, media studies, communication models, critical thinking, message analysis, cultural communication

courses.title: Elementary French I
courses.document:
FREN 101 - Elementary French I
Department: FREN | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Elementary French I is a carefully sequenced and highly interactive presentation of French language and culture in a media-rich course environment. To successfully take this course, students should be motivated with a sincere desire to learn about French language and francophone cultures, and be comfortable with computer technologies.

Good for students interested in: french language, basic grammar, vocabulary development, pronunciation, francophone culture, language comprehension, conversational skills, listening skills

courses.title: Our World: Human Geography
courses.document:
GEOG 100 - Our World: Human Geography
Department: GEOG | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

A geographical introduction to how humans shape our world, with attention also given to how it shapes us. Themes may include: culture, economic activities, environmental change, globalization, politics, population, resources, and urbanization.

Good for students interested in: human geography, cultural geography, economic geography, environmental change, globalization, population studies, urbanization, spatial analysis

courses.title: Climate Change, Water, Society
courses.document:
GEOG 104 - Climate Change, Water, Society
Department: GEOG | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

An examination of climate change, its interaction with water availability, and how humans cope with these altered circumstances.

Good for students interested in: climate change, water resources, hydrology, environmental impact, human adaptation, sustainability, ecosystem dynamics, resource management

courses.title: Digital Earth
courses.document:
GEOG 150 - Digital Earth
Department: GEOG | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

Practical applications of geographic information techniques for analysis and problem-solving in multiple contexts.

Good for students interested in: geographic information systems, spatial analysis, remote sensing, cartography, data visualization, geospatial data, digital mapping, problem-solving

courses.title: Gender Talk
courses.document:
GSWS 101 - Gender Talk
Department: GSWS | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

An interdisciplinary study of the social and cultural construction of gender, and how ideas about masculinity and feminity shape current issues, knowledge, popular culture, and social policy.

Good for students interested in: gender theory, masculinity studies, femininity studies, social construction, cultural analysis, popular culture, social policy, interdisciplinary studies

courses.title: Discrete Math I
courses.document:
MACM 101 - Discrete Math I
Department: MACM | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q, B-Sci | Prerequisites: BC Pre-Calculus 12 or BC Calculus 12 (or equivalent), or any of MATH 100, 150, 151, 154, 157.

Introduction to graph theory, trees, induction, automata theory, formal reasoning, modular arithmetic.

Good for students interested in: graph theory, trees, mathematical induction, automata theory, formal reasoning, modular arithmetic, discrete mathematics, proof techniques

metadata.prerequisites_raw: BC Pre-Calculus 12 or BC Calculus 12 (or equivalent), or any of MATH 100, 150, 151, 154, 157.

courses.title: Physics for Life Sciences I
courses.document:
PHYS 101 - Physics for Life Sciences I
Department: PHYS | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q, B-Sci | Prerequisites: BC Principles of Physics 12 or PHYS 100 or equivalent, with a minimum grade of C-. This prerequisite may be waived, at the discretion of the department, as determined by the student's performance on a...

Force and motion, conservation of energy and momentum, fluids, properties of soft matter and thermal physics with applications taken from the life sciences.

Good for students interested in: force and motion, conservation of energy, conservation of momentum, fluid mechanics, soft matter physics, thermal physics, biophysics applications, energy transfer

metadata.prerequisites_raw: BC Principles of Physics 12 or PHYS 100 or equivalent, with a minimum grade of C-. This prerequisite may be waived, at the discretion of the department, as determined by the student's performance on a regularly scheduled PHYS 100 final exam. Please consult the physics advisor for further details. Corequisite: MATH 150 or 151 or 154 or 157; BISC 100 or 101 or 102. Recommended Corequisite: PHYS 132.

courses.title: Physics for Life Sciences II
courses.document:
PHYS 102 - Physics for Life Sciences II
Department: PHYS | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q, B-Sci | Prerequisites: PHYS 101 or 120 or 125 or 140; MATH 150 or 151 or 154 or 157; both with a minimum grade of C-. Corequisite: BISC 100 or 101 or 102. Recommended Corequisites: MATH 152, 155 or 158; PHYS 133.

Waves and optics; electricity and magnetism; modern physics emphasizing radioactivity, with applications taken from the life sciences.

Good for students interested in: waves, optics, electricity, magnetism, radioactivity, modern physics, life sciences applications, electromagnetic theory

metadata.prerequisites_raw: PHYS 101 or 120 or 125 or 140; MATH 150 or 151 or 154 or 157; both with a minimum grade of C-. Corequisite: BISC 100 or 101 or 102. Recommended Corequisites: MATH 152, 155 or 158; PHYS 133.

courses.title: Optics, Electricity, Magnetism
courses.document:
PHYS 121 - Optics, Electricity, Magnetism
Department: PHYS | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q, B-Sci | Prerequisites: PHYS 120 or 125 or 140, with a minimum grade of C-, or PHYS 101 with a minimum grade of B. Corequisite: MATH 152 or 155. Recommended Corequisite: PHYS 133.

A general calculus-based introduction to electricity, magnetism and optics. Topics include electricity, magnetism, simple circuits, optics and topics from applied physics.

Good for students interested in: electricity, magnetism, optics, simple circuits, applied physics, calculus-based analysis, electromagnetic theory, wave propagation

metadata.prerequisites_raw: PHYS 120 or 125 or 140, with a minimum grade of C-, or PHYS 101 with a minimum grade of B. Corequisite: MATH 152 or 155. Recommended Corequisite: PHYS 133.

courses.title: Intro.Psychology I
courses.document:
PSYC 100 - Intro.Psychology I
Department: PSYC | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

Acquaints the student with the major issues in contemporary psychology and considers the historical antecedents. Special attention is given to questions of methodology and research design in psychology. Topics in physiological psychology, perception, learning and motivation are considered.

Good for students interested in: psychological research methods, physiological psychology, perception, learning, motivation, research design, history of psychology, experimental psychology

courses.title: Global Change
courses.document:
REM 100 - Global Change
Department: REM | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

The Earth is experiencing the most dramatic environmental changes it has for thousands of years. How did we end up here? Provides an interdisciplinary perspective on the forces behind our ever-increasing environmental footprint. Highlights how ideologies and societal structures have shaped how we interact with the environment and explores the necessary changes for a more sustainable future.

Good for students interested in: global change, environmental science, sustainability, human-environment interaction, environmental ethics, climate change, societal impact, interdisciplinary analysis

courses.title: Biology in Everyday Life
courses.document:
BISC 113 - Biology in Everyday Life
Department: BISC | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Sci | Prerequisites: None

Emphasizes the biology relevant to everyday life and the methods by which biologists address scientific questions. Topics include: evolution; human inheritance, reproduction, and development; nutrition, activity, wellness and cancer; agriculture and genetic engineering; and biodiversity and human affairs. Students with a minimum grade of C in Biology 12 (or equivalent), who are considering a BISC major, are encouraged to proceed directly to BISC 101 and 102.

Good for students interested in: evolution, human inheritance, reproduction, nutrition, genetic engineering, biodiversity, scientific methods, wellness

courses.title: Music Appreciation 21st Cent.
courses.document:
CA 142 - Music Appreciation 21st Cent.
Department: CA | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

21st Century Music Appreciation aims to develop a critical ear and advanced listening skills. The course will take a post-modern approach to appreciation in that it will present a diversity of music from many cultures, styles, and periods in an effort to discover similarities, differences, and defining characteristics.

Good for students interested in: music appreciation, advanced listening skills, critical listening, post-modern music, world music, music analysis, cultural music studies, contemporary music

courses.title: Soc. Issues & Cmns. Strategies
courses.document:
CMPT 105W - Soc. Issues & Cmns. Strategies
Department: CMPT | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: W | Prerequisites: None

This course teaches the fundamentals of informative and persuasive communication for professional engineers and computer scientists. A principal goal of this course is to assist students in thinking critically about various contemporary technical, social, and ethical issues. It focuses on communicating technical information clearly and concisely, managing issues of persuasion when communicating with diverse audiences, presentation skills, and teamwork.

Good for students interested in: technical communication, persuasive communication, critical thinking, ethical issues, social issues, presentation skills, teamwork, communication strategies

courses.title: Introduction to Criminology
courses.document:
CRIM 101 - Introduction to Criminology
Department: CRIM | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

Introduces terms and concepts commonly used in criminology. Students explore criminology as a body of knowledge and a profession, examining its subject matter, its position within the social sciences, and its relationship with other disciplines. Covers the history and evolution of criminological thought. Discussions address different levels of explanation in criminology, crime typologies, the relationship between theory and practice, and the application of criminological research in shaping modern criminal policy. Emphasizes the role of empirical research in understanding crime patterns, evaluating theories, and informing policy decisions.

Good for students interested in: criminology, crime typologies, criminological theory, empirical research, social sciences, criminal policy, history of criminology, research methods

courses.title: Rise and Fall of the Dinosaurs
courses.document:
EASC 103 - Rise and Fall of the Dinosaurs
Department: EASC | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Sci | Prerequisites: None

Dinosaurs ruled our planet for nearly 150 million years until the abrupt extinction of all non-avian (non-bird) dinosaurs, approximately 66 million years ago. We examine geologic time, fossils and biological classification, and investigate the rise and fall of the theropods, sauropods, ornithopods, stegosaurs, ankylosaurs, ceratopsians, and pachycephalosaurs.

Good for students interested in: paleontology, geologic time, fossil analysis, dinosaur classification, extinction events, theropods, sauropods, evolutionary biology

courses.title: Principles of Microeconomics
courses.document:
ECON 103 - Principles of Microeconomics
Department: ECON | Level: 100 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: None

The principal elements of theory concerning utility and value, price and costs, factor analysis, productivity, labor organization, competition and monopoly, and the theory of the firm.

Good for students interested in: utility theory, value theory, price analysis, cost structures, factor markets, productivity measurement, labor economics, market competition

courses.title: Environmental Science
courses.document:
EVSC 100 - Environmental Science
Department: EVSC | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Blended
WQB: B-Sci | Prerequisites: None

Introduces students to the study of environmental science. Lecture material spans contributing disciplines, emphasizing integration of diverse concepts to understand environmental problems. Tutorials develop core academic skills in environmental science context.

Good for students interested in: environmental science, ecology, sustainability, environmental policy, data analysis, scientific writing, critical thinking, interdisciplinary studies

courses.title: The Making of Modern Europe
courses.document:
HIST 106 - The Making of Modern Europe
Department: HIST | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

An introduction to the major political, social, economic, cultural, and intellectual developments that have formed modern European society.

Good for students interested in: modern european history, political developments, social change, economic history, cultural movements, intellectual history, historical analysis, critical thinking

courses.title: Foundations of Health Science
courses.document:
HSCI 130 - Foundations of Health Science
Department: HSCI | Level: 100 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

How health, illness and disease are defined and measured for individuals and populations. Research strategies used to identify how health, illness and disease are distributed across human populations and how environmental, socio-economic, demographic, biological, behavioural and political factors influence individual and population health.

Good for students interested in: health measurement, epidemiology, population health, disease distribution, environmental health, socio-economic factors, demographic analysis, health research methods

courses.title: Cmns & Language
courses.document:
LING 100 - Cmns & Language
Department: LING | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Blended
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

Explores the foundations of human language from a variety of perspectives. Young children acquire language effortlessly. How is this possible, and why is it so much more challenging to learn a new language later in life? How does the human brain use complex grammatical systems to communicate? Students will learn new ways to think critically about language and communication. Open to all students.

Good for students interested in: language acquisition, linguistics, grammar, communication, critical thinking, cognitive science, language development, psycholinguistics

courses.title: The Wonder of Words
courses.document:
LING 111 - The Wonder of Words
Department: LING | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

Introduces students to theories about words and vocabulary. Explores topics such as the roots of the English vocabulary, how we create new words and how we learn them. Also discusses practical applications such as constructed languages for use in science fiction, and word recognition in artificial intelligence. Open to all students.

Good for students interested in: lexicology, word formation, vocabulary acquisition, etymology, constructed languages, word recognition, language development, computational linguistics

courses.title: Critical Thinking
courses.document:
PHIL 105 - Critical Thinking
Department: PHIL | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

An introduction to the tools of reasoning used in everyday life and in science. The overall aim of the course is to understand what makes good reasoning good, what makes bad reasoning bad, and how to do more of the former and less of the latter. Topics include: construction, analysis, and evaluation of arguments; logic and probability; updating beliefs and making decisions; designing experiments; interpreting statistics; identifying fallacies and biases. Open to all students.

Good for students interested in: critical thinking, argument analysis, logic, probability, decision making, experimental design, statistics interpretation, fallacies and biases

courses.title: Logic and Reasoning
courses.document:
PHIL 110 - Logic and Reasoning
Department: PHIL | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: None

An introduction to the theory of deductive reasoning. We consider deductive arguments in philosophy, in everyday life, and in mathematical proofs, and discuss what distinguishes valid inferences from fallacies. The course will cover propositional logic and first-order logic. Open to all students.

Good for students interested in: deductive reasoning, propositional logic, first-order logic, valid inferences, logical fallacies, argument analysis, mathematical proofs, critical thinking

courses.title: Intro Politics and Government
courses.document:
POL 100 - Intro Politics and Government
Department: POL | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

A comprehensive introduction to the study of politics and government for both political science majors and students specializing in other disciplines. The course will explore the major concepts, methods, approaches and issues in political science, as well as the primary components of government structure and the political process.

Good for students interested in: political science, government structure, political processes, political theory, comparative politics, research methods, critical analysis, public policy

courses.title: Shamans,Sacrifice&Psychedelics
courses.document:
ARCH 226 - Shamans,Sacrifice&Psychedelics
Department: ARCH | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Charts the emergence and changes in the expression of human religious behavior. It covers the earliest rituals of the Palaeolithic, the importance of fertility cults, ancestor cults, alliance rituals, shamans, witchcraft, and monotheism.

Good for students interested in: religious behavior, paleolithic rituals, fertility cults, ancestor cults, alliance rituals, shamanism, witchcraft, monotheism

courses.title: Creative Music & Sound Pract.
courses.document:
CA 140 - Creative Music & Sound Pract.
Department: CA | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Looks at the issues involved in being a creative musical artist in the 21st century. Topics include historical context, race and gender, the role and influence of politics, music and identity, appropriation, art music, functional music, and hybrid practices. May be of particular interest to students in other departments.

Good for students interested in: creative music, sound practice, music and identity, race and gender in music, political influence in music, music appropriation, art music, hybrid musical practices

courses.title: Introductory Chem.
courses.document:
CHEM 110 - Introductory Chem.
Department: CHEM | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: Q, B-Sci | Prerequisites: Pre-Calculus 12 (or equivalent), MATH 100 (may be taken concurrently), or permission of the department. No previous training in chemistry is required for this course.

General fundamental concepts and nomenclature; stoichiometry and chemical calculations; nuclear and atomic structures, chemical bonding; properties of gases, liquids, solids and solutions; chemical kinetics and chemical equilibrium. This course has the same lecture component as CHEM 111 but no laboratory work. Students who intend to take further laboratory courses in chemistry should take CHEM 111 instead.

Good for students interested in: stoichiometry, chemical bonding, atomic structure, chemical kinetics, chemical equilibrium, gas properties, solution chemistry, chemical nomenclature

metadata.prerequisites_raw: Pre-Calculus 12 (or equivalent), MATH 100 (may be taken concurrently), or permission of the department. No previous training in chemistry is required for this course.

courses.title: Dynamic Earth
courses.document:
EASC 101 - Dynamic Earth
Department: EASC | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Sci | Prerequisites: None

Dynamic Earth offers an introduction to minerals, rocks, geologic resources and processes. Plate tectonics is the unifying theory of geology and is the focus as we learn how the Earth changes over geologic time and results in the formation of volcanoes and mountain belts, faults, folds and earthquakes.

Good for students interested in: minerals, rocks, geologic resources, plate tectonics, volcanoes, mountain belts, faults, earthquakes

courses.title: Principles of Macroeconomics
courses.document:
ECON 105 - Principles of Macroeconomics
Department: ECON | Level: 100 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: None

The principal elements of theory concerning money and income, distribution, social accounts, public finance, international trade, comparative systems, and development and growth.

Good for students interested in: macroeconomic theory, money and banking, income distribution, public finance, international trade, economic development, social accounting, growth models

courses.title: Aging and Society
courses.document:
GERO 101 - Aging and Society
Department: GERO | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

Introduces the social, psychological, and physical dimensions of aging. Largely based on the Canadian context, but will also include international research and knowledge.

Good for students interested in: aging, social gerontology, psychological aspects of aging, physical health in aging, canadian aging studies, international aging research, lifespan development, aging and society

courses.title: Histories of Technology
courses.document:
HIST 111 - Histories of Technology
Department: HIST | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

An introduction to the social and cultural contexts and historical effects of major developments in technology.

Good for students interested in: technology history, social context, cultural impact, technological developments, historical analysis, innovation studies, critical thinking, societal change

courses.title: Human Biology
courses.document:
HSCI 100 - Human Biology
Department: HSCI | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Sci | Prerequisites: None

An examination of the biological processes that underlie human health and well-being, with emphasis on the evolutionary and ecological influences affecting human populations.

Good for students interested in: human biology, evolutionary biology, ecology, human health, biological processes, population biology, physiology, environmental influences

courses.title: Global Perspectives on Health
courses.document:
HSCI 160 - Global Perspectives on Health
Department: HSCI | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

An introduction to the differences in health and health services among the nations of the globe. Vulnerable sub-populations worldwide and their special health needs. Mechanisms whereby events in one country can impact health in another. Future worldwide health risks, their economic and health consequences. SARS, avian 'flu,' West Nile virus, 'mad cow disease,' antibiotic resistant malaria or tuberculosis. Dangers to rich and poor nations from ignoring health problems in developing world.

Good for students interested in: global health, health disparities, vulnerable populations, infectious diseases, health systems, epidemiology, health policy, global health risks

courses.title: Game Studies
courses.document:
IAT 210 - Game Studies
Department: IAT | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Reviews the history of games, tracing the evolution of game design from board and card games through the latest electronic products. Examines the medium of games through various lenses: games as rules (game design), games as play (game experience), and games as culture (culture within games, and role of games and game cultures).

Good for students interested in: game design, game history, game experience, game culture, rules analysis, play theory, cultural studies, interactive media

courses.title: Intro to International Studies
courses.document:
IS 101 - Intro to International Studies
Department: IS | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Introduces the interdisciplinary field of International Studies to all undergraduates and IS majors. Examines the major global challenges of our time, including poverty and inequality, environmental degradation, nationalism, civil war, and armed conflict. Explores the challenge of global governance and global citizenship.

Good for students interested in: global challenges, poverty and inequality, environmental degradation, nationalism, civil war, armed conflict, global governance, global citizenship

courses.title: Japanese I
courses.document:
JAPN 100 - Japanese I
Department: JAPN | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Introduction to Japanese for students with no background in that language. Introduces basic oral and written skills, and the three Japanese writing systems (Hiragana, Katakana and Kanji). Students who took Japanese courses in secondary school and/or with previous knowledge of Japanese may need to be evaluated for placement into JAPN 110 or higher level of courses and are required to contact the instructor before enrollment.

Good for students interested in: japanese language, basic oral skills, basic written skills, hiragana, katakana, kanji, language acquisition, pronunciation

courses.title: The Science of Speech
courses.document:
LING 190 - The Science of Speech
Department: LING | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

Introduces the scientific study of speech, focusing on the mechanisms of speech production and perception, the ways in which speech is described and analyzed, the relationship between speech and technology, and the practical applications of phonetic science. Open to all students.

Good for students interested in: speech production, speech perception, phonetics, acoustic analysis, speech technology, articulatory mechanisms, auditory processing, phonetic transcription

courses.title: Intro-Anthropology
courses.document:
SA 101 - Intro-Anthropology
Department: SA | Level: 100 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

Anthropology asks fundamental questions about how people live and interact in different contexts. Engages with contemporary social life around the world, including the relations among people, ideas, and things. Provides analytical tools to help understand the role of culture and society in our lives.

Good for students interested in: cultural anthropology, social interaction, ethnography, cultural analysis, societal structures, qualitative research, human behavior, cultural diversity

courses.title: Introductory Spanish I
courses.document:
SPAN 100 - Introductory Spanish I
Department: SPAN | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Blended
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Introduction to Spanish for students with little or no previous background in that language. Course develops Spanish language acquisition through listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills. Practical and situational materials are employed to underline the ties between language and culture. By the end of the term, students will have acquired basic conversational skills and an elementary reading facility. (A1 level of CEFR). Students with previous Spanish training should contact the department for placement.

Good for students interested in: spanish language acquisition, basic conversational spanish, listening comprehension, speaking skills, reading skills, writing skills, language and culture, beginner spanish grammar

courses.title: Ancient Egypt and Africa
courses.document:
ARCH 252 - Ancient Egypt and Africa
Department: ARCH | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Exploration of the major cultural developments in Africa from the origin of humankind to the rise of several ancient civilizations, with special emphasis on ancient Egypt. Students are exposed to various approaches taken by palaeoanthropologists, prehistoric archaeologists, historians and Egyptologists.

Good for students interested in: ancient civilizations, palaeoanthropology, prehistoric archaeology, egyptology, cultural developments, african history, archaeological methods, historical analysis

courses.title: Business Fundamentals
courses.document:
BUS 200 - Business Fundamentals
Department: BUS | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

Explore the fundamentals of modern business and organizational management. Working with case studies, students will build upon the basics of revenue, profits, contribution and costs, as well as integrate advanced aspects of business models, innovation, competitive advantage, core competence, and strategic analysis.

Good for students interested in: business models, organizational management, strategic analysis, revenue and profit analysis, competitive advantage, innovation, cost management, case study analysis

courses.title: Business Statistics
courses.document:
BUS 232 - Business Statistics
Department: BUS | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: None

An introduction to business statistics (descriptive and inferential statistics) with a heavy emphasis on applications and the use of EXCEL. Students will be required to use statistical applications to solve business problems.

Good for students interested in: descriptive statistics, inferential statistics, data analysis, excel applications, probability theory, hypothesis testing, statistical modeling, business decision-making

courses.title: General Chemistry I
courses.document:
CHEM 120 - General Chemistry I
Department: CHEM | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q, B-Sci | Prerequisites: Chemistry 12 with a minimum grade of B, or CHEM 110 or 111 with a minimum grade of C-.

Atomic and molecular structure; chemical bonding; thermochemistry; elements; periodic table; gases, liquids, solids, and solutions. This course has the same lecture component as CHEM 121 but no laboratory work. Students who intend to take further courses in chemistry should also take CHEM 125 or alternatively take CHEM 121 instead.

Good for students interested in: atomic structure, molecular structure, chemical bonding, thermochemistry, periodic table, states of matter, solutions, chemical properties

metadata.prerequisites_raw: Chemistry 12 with a minimum grade of B, or CHEM 110 or 111 with a minimum grade of C-.

courses.title: General Chemistry Laboratory I
courses.document:
CHEM 125 - General Chemistry Laboratory I
Department: CHEM | Level: 100 | Units: 1
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q, B-Sci | Prerequisites: Chemistry 12 with a minimum grade of C, or CHEM 109 or CHEM 111 with a minimum grade of C-. Corequisite: CHEM 120.

Experiments in atomic and molecular structure, chemical bonding and reactivity, thermochemistry, gases, liquids, solids and solutions. This course has the same laboratory component as CHEM 121.

Good for students interested in: atomic structure, molecular structure, chemical bonding, reactivity, thermochemistry, gas laws, solutions, laboratory techniques

metadata.prerequisites_raw: Chemistry 12 with a minimum grade of C, or CHEM 109 or CHEM 111 with a minimum grade of C-. Corequisite: CHEM 120.

courses.title: Mandarin Chinese I
courses.document:
CHIN 100 - Mandarin Chinese I
Department: CHIN | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Blended
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Introduction to Mandarin Chinese for students with no prior background or instruction in that language. CHIN 100 is a beginners course in basic oral and written skills. Students will be assessed through a placement process at the beginning of the term.

Good for students interested in: mandarin chinese, basic oral skills, written chinese, pronunciation, vocabulary development, chinese grammar, language acquisition, listening comprehension

courses.title: Intro to Technology & Society
courses.document:
CMNS 253W - Intro to Technology & Society
Department: CMNS | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: W | Prerequisites: None

An introduction to new communication/information technologies, seen as new media of communication: the technologies, their uses, and the social issues arising from them.

Good for students interested in: communication technologies, new media, information technology, social impact, digital communication, media theory, technology ethics, societal change

courses.title: Studies in History
courses.document:
HIST 185 - Studies in History
Department: HIST | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Special topics. Students may repeat this course for further credit under a different topic.

Good for students interested in: historical analysis, historiography, primary sources, critical thinking, research methods, thematic studies, historical interpretation, periodization

courses.title: Intro to Religious Studies
courses.document:
HUM 130 - Intro to Religious Studies
Department: HUM | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Introduction to concepts central to the academic study of religion, exploring various relevant methodologies. Provides a framework for understanding the many ways in which humans experience the phenomenon of the sacred through symbol, ritual, doctrine, and engagement, in a variety of religious traditions and cultures. Presents case studies in Ancient (Greek, Mesopotamian, and Egyptian), Abrahamic (Judaism, Christianity, and Islam), and secular (post-) religions.

Good for students interested in: religious studies, sacred symbolism, ritual analysis, comparative religion, religious doctrines, cultural anthropology, methodology in religion, ancient religions

courses.title: Design Commun and Collab
courses.document:
IAT 103W - Design Commun and Collab
Department: IAT | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: W | Prerequisites: None

Teaches essential skills for negotiating first-year course work successfully. Covers the principles, practice and understanding of effective communication, research, critical thinking, and teamwork with a focus on issues central to the practice of IAT as a profession. Presents opportunities to practice and develop interpersonal skills and make that expertise transferable to the workplace.

Good for students interested in: effective communication, research skills, critical thinking, teamwork, interpersonal skills, negotiation, collaboration, professional practice

courses.title: Equality & Inequality at Work
courses.document:
LBST 100 - Equality & Inequality at Work
Department: LBST | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

Introduces concepts of equality, inequality, diversity, and inclusion as we experience them at work. Includes discussion of what counts as work, who does paid and unpaid work, and how workers challenge inequality and discrimination. Examines how contemporary experiences in Canada of inequality at work are shaped by ongoing colonialism, racialization, gendering, class and other forms of social difference.

Good for students interested in: equality, inequality, diversity, inclusion, workplace discrimination, social difference, colonialism, racialization

courses.title: Process of Prof. Writing
courses.document:
MSE 101W - Process of Prof. Writing
Department: MSE | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: W | Prerequisites: None

The course teaches fundamentals of informative and persuasive communication for professional engineers and computer scientists in order to assist students in thinking critically about various contemporary technical, social, and ethical issues. It focuses on communicating technical information clearly and concisely, managing issues of persuasion when communicating with diverse audiences, presentation skills, and teamwork.

Good for students interested in: technical communication, persuasive writing, critical thinking, ethical issues, presentation skills, teamwork, professional writing, audience analysis

courses.title: Education Psychology
courses.document:
EDUC 220 - Education Psychology
Department: EDUC | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

A survey of educational research and theories concerning motivation, learning, development, and individual differences in classroom settings. May be applied towards the certificate in liberal arts.

Good for students interested in: educational research, motivation theories, learning processes, human development, individual differences, classroom dynamics, cognitive development, educational psychology

courses.title: Intro. Philosophy of Education
courses.document:
EDUC 230 - Intro. Philosophy of Education
Department: EDUC | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Provides prospective teachers and others interested in education an opportunity to examine a variety of educational problems from a philosophical perspective. The central concern of the course is to elucidate the nature of education as a phenomenon distinct from such activities as training, schooling, and socialization. May be applied towards the certificate in liberal arts.

Good for students interested in: philosophy of education, educational theory, nature of education, critical thinking, educational problems, socialization, schooling, educational philosophy

courses.title: Geog.Info.Science I
courses.document:
GEOG 255 - Geog.Info.Science I
Department: GEOG | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: None

A basic overview of Geographical Information Systems and Science; GIS software, hardware, data structures and models; spatial data, operations and algorithms; practical applications and limitations.

Good for students interested in: geographical information systems, spatial data, gis software, data structures, spatial algorithms, geographic data models, spatial analysis, gis applications

courses.title: Studies in History
courses.document:
HIST 285 - Studies in History
Department: HIST | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

Special topics.

Good for students interested in: historical analysis, historiography, primary sources, thematic history, research methods, critical thinking, cultural history, archival research

courses.title: Digi, Virtual & AI Photography
courses.document:
IAT 244 - Digi, Virtual & AI Photography
Department: IAT | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

An introduction to digital photography using mobile technologies, free software and online platforms. The focus of the course is on developing a final portfolio that demonstrates a wide range of technical, aesthetic, stylistic, genre and conceptual approaches to digital photography, including the use of generative AI platforms and real-time rendered virtual image production. Students are encouraged to experiment and develop their own eye and approaches, while learning the fundamentals of digital image production and workflows, including output for web and print.

Good for students interested in: digital photography, mobile photography, generative ai, virtual image production, digital image workflows, photo editing software, aesthetic development, portfolio creation

courses.title: Introduction to Linguistics
courses.document:
LING 220 - Introduction to Linguistics
Department: LING | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

Explores how language works. Introduces students to the systematic nature of language by exploring the patterns of sounds, words, sentences and meanings in English and other languages. Develops problem-solving and critical thinking skills through hands-on training in pattern recognition and language data analysis. Open to all students.

Good for students interested in: phonetics, syntax, semantics, morphology, language analysis, pattern recognition, critical thinking, data analysis

courses.title: General Biology
courses.document:
BISC 101 - General Biology
Department: BISC | Level: 100 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Sci | Prerequisites: Biology 12 (or equivalent) with a minimum grade of C (or BISC 100 with a minimum grade of C-, or BISC 113 with a minimum grade of C+, or BPK 105 with a minimum grade of C+, or HSCI 100 with a minimum ...

Introduction to the molecular, cellular and physiological mechanisms of living organisms (microorganisms, plants, animals). Lecture and lab topics include cell structure and function, flow of genetic information, enzyme function, metabolism, whole organism form and function (circulation, gas exchange, nutrition, osmoregulation). BISC 101 and 102 can be taken in either order.

Good for students interested in: cell structure, genetic information flow, enzyme function, metabolism, physiology, molecular biology, cellular mechanisms, organismal biology

metadata.prerequisites_raw: Biology 12 (or equivalent) with a minimum grade of C (or BISC 100 with a minimum grade of C-, or BISC 113 with a minimum grade of C+, or BPK 105 with a minimum grade of C+, or HSCI 100 with a minimum grade of C+); and Chemistry 12 (or equivalent) with a minimum grade of C (or CHEM 111 with a minimum grade of C-).

courses.title: STT-Learning to Listen
courses.document:
CA 105 - STT-Learning to Listen
Department: CA | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

Through listening-based analysis, students will unpack popular songs to gain an understanding of topics like instrumentation, structure, harmony, rhythm, melody, production, and style. Tools such as Western staff and rhythmic notation will be introduced as means to support listening-based/aural analysis, however all assessments will be based on listening rather than writing.

Good for students interested in: aural analysis, music theory, instrumentation, song structure, harmony, rhythm, melody, music production

courses.title: General Chemistry II
courses.document:
CHEM 122 - General Chemistry II
Department: CHEM | Level: 100 | Units: 2
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: CHEM 120 or 121 with a minimum grade of C-.

Chemical equilibria; electrochemistry; chemical thermodynamics; kinetics. Students who intend to take further laboratory courses in chemistry should take CHEM 122 concurrently with CHEM 126.

Good for students interested in: chemical equilibria, electrochemistry, chemical thermodynamics, kinetics, reaction rates, energy transformations, chemical reactions, quantitative analysis

metadata.prerequisites_raw: CHEM 120 or 121 with a minimum grade of C-.

courses.title: Communication Social Change
courses.document:
CMNS 130 - Communication Social Change
Department: CMNS | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

An introduction to the forms, theories and institutions of communication as they relate to broader social change, with a focus on the political, economic and regulatory shifts characterizing Canadian and transnational media systems. This course is required for a major, honours or minor in communication.

Good for students interested in: communication theories, social change, media systems, political communication, economic communication, regulatory frameworks, transnational media, critical analysis

courses.title: Hist of Educ in Western World
courses.document:
EDUC 250 - Hist of Educ in Western World
Department: EDUC | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

A study of major trends in educational practice from antiquity to the present. May be applied towards the certificate in liberal arts.

Good for students interested in: educational history, pedagogical theories, historical trends in education, western educational systems, curriculum development, critical analysis, educational philosophy, societal impact of education

courses.title: Elementary French II
courses.document:
FREN 102 - Elementary French II
Department: FREN | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: FREN 101, FREN 120, or FREN 121 or consult with a French advisor.

Elementary French II is a carefully sequenced and highly interactive presentation of French language and culture in a media-rich course environment. To successfully take this course, students should be motivated with a sincere desire to learn about French language and francophone cultures, and be comfortable with computer technologies. This course continues on where FREN 101 left off to develop new pathways.

Good for students interested in: french language, francophone cultures, language acquisition, conversational skills, grammar and syntax, listening comprehension, vocabulary building, cultural awareness

metadata.prerequisites_raw: FREN 101, FREN 120, or FREN 121 or consult with a French advisor.

courses.title: Islamic India
courses.document:
HIST 252 - Islamic India
Department: HIST | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: None

A survey of the cultural patterns, social and political forces, and historical contexts that have shaped the Islamic period of Indian history. Special attention will be directed toward the Mughal empire and its decline.

Good for students interested in: islamic history, mughal empire, cultural patterns, political forces, social history, historical analysis, south asian studies, empire decline

courses.title: Media Across Cultures
courses.document:
IAT 206W - Media Across Cultures
Department: IAT | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: W, B-Hum | Prerequisites: IAT 103W with a minimum grade of C-.

Introduces a discursive framework for media, design and cultural interfaces enabling students to interpret, negotiate, and engage with new media with an awareness of the significance of cultural and contextual difference. Assessment is based on written and project work.

Good for students interested in: media studies, cultural analysis, new media, intercultural communication, media design, critical thinking, cultural interfaces, media interpretation

metadata.prerequisites_raw: IAT 103W with a minimum grade of C-.

courses.title: Calculus II
courses.document:
MATH 152 - Calculus II
Department: MATH | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: MATH 150 or 151 or 155, with a minimum grade of C-; or MATH 154 or 157, with a grade of at least B.

Riemann sum, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, definite, indefinite and improper integrals, approximate integration, integration techniques, applications of integration. First-order separable differential equations and growth models. Sequences and series, series tests, power series, convergence and applications of power series.

Good for students interested in: riemann sums, fundamental theorem of calculus, integration techniques, differential equations, growth models, sequences and series, power series, convergence tests

metadata.prerequisites_raw: MATH 150 or 151 or 155, with a minimum grade of C-; or MATH 154 or 157, with a grade of at least B.

courses.title: Math for the Life Sciences II
courses.document:
MATH 155 - Math for the Life Sciences II
Department: MATH | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: MATH 150, 151 or 154, with a minimum grade of C-; or MATH 157 with a grade of at least B.

Designed for students specializing in the life sciences. Topics include: vectors and matrices, partial derivatives, multi-dimensional integrals, systems of differential equations, compartment models, graphs and networks, and their applications to the life sciences; mathematical models of multi-component biological processes and their implementation and analysis using software. Students planning to take MATH 251 are recommended to consider MATH 152 as the prerequisite pathway. See an advisor to determine what may be best for you.

Good for students interested in: vectors and matrices, partial derivatives, multi-dimensional integrals, systems of differential equations, compartment models, graphs and networks, mathematical modeling, biological processes analysis

metadata.prerequisites_raw: MATH 150, 151 or 154, with a minimum grade of C-; or MATH 157 with a grade of at least B.

courses.title: Intro.Psychology II
courses.document:
PSYC 102 - Intro.Psychology II
Department: PSYC | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: Recommended: PSYC 100.

Acquaints the student with major issues in contemporary psychology and considers their historical antecedents. Topics in learning, cognition, social psychology and abnormal psychology are considered.

Good for students interested in: learning, cognition, social psychology, abnormal psychology, historical psychology, psychological theories, behavior analysis, mental disorders

metadata.prerequisites_raw: Recommended: PSYC 100.

courses.title: Anth and Contemporary Life
courses.document:
SA 201W - Anth and Contemporary Life
Department: SA | Level: 200 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: W, B-Soc | Prerequisites: Recommended: SA 101.

An introduction to the anthropological perspective as applied to the organization of everyday life in contemporary settings. Introduces positivist, interpretive, and critical interpretive approaches to the analysis of social actions, identities, and values as enacted in space and time.

Good for students interested in: anthropological perspective, social organization, contemporary life, positivist approach, interpretive approach, critical interpretive approach, social actions, identity analysis

metadata.prerequisites_raw: Recommended: SA 101.

courses.title: Illness, Culture and Society
courses.document:
SA 218 - Illness, Culture and Society
Department: SA | Level: 200 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: None

Health and well-being are social experiences. How do assumptions about the body, the self, and social relations operate in medical spheres? Introduces anthropological perspectives on illness and healing as a means of exploring the social existence of the body.

Good for students interested in: medical anthropology, social determinants of health, illness narratives, body and self, healing practices, cultural perceptions of illness, health and society, anthropological theory

courses.title: General Biology
courses.document:
BISC 102 - General Biology
Department: BISC | Level: 100 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person

BISC 101 and 102 may be taken in either order.
