metadata.prerequisites_raw: JAPN 100 or equivalent. Students who took Japanese courses in secondary school and/or with previous knowledge of Japanese may need to be evaluated for placement into JAPN 110 or higher level of courses and are required to contact the instructor before enrollment.

courses.title: Mathematics for Teachers
courses.document:
MATH 190 - Mathematics for Teachers
Department: MATH | Level: 100 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: Pre-Calculus 11 or Foundations of Mathematics 11 (or equivalent) with a grade of at least B, or SFU FAN X99 course with a grade of at least C, or achieving a satisfactory grade on the Simon Fraser Uni...

Designed for students pursuing a career as an elementary school teacher. Topics are drawn from number systems as well as plane, solid, and metric geometry. Examination of the historical and cultural development of mathematical ideas and their place in contemporary mathematics. Emphasis on deep understanding of mathematical concepts and on multiple representations: physical, pictorial, and symbolic. Detailed topics include: problem solving, bases, whole and fractional numbers and their arithmetic operations, number theory, ratios, rates, percent, polygons, polyhedra, symmetries, transformations, and measurements.

Good for students interested in: number systems, geometry, mathematical concepts, problem solving, number theory, ratios and rates, transformations, measurement

metadata.prerequisites_raw: Pre-Calculus 11 or Foundations of Mathematics 11 (or equivalent) with a grade of at least B, or SFU FAN X99 course with a grade of at least C, or achieving a satisfactory grade on the Simon Fraser University Quantitative Placement Test. This course may not be counted toward the Mathematics minor, major or honours degree requirements. Students who have taken, have received transfer credit for, or are currently taking MATH 150, 151, 154 or 157 may not take MATH 190 for credit without permission from the Department of Mathematics. Intended to be particularly accessible to students who are not specializing in mathematics.

courses.title: Applied Linear Algebra
courses.document:
MATH 232 - Applied Linear Algebra
Department: MATH | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: MATH 150 or 151 or MACM 101, with a minimum grade of C-; or MATH 154 or 157, both with a grade of at least B.

Linear equations, matrices, determinants. Introduction to vector spaces and linear transformations and bases. Complex numbers. Eigenvalues and eigenvectors; diagonalization. Inner products and orthogonality; least squares problems. An emphasis on applications involving matrix and vector calculations.

Good for students interested in: linear equations, matrices, determinants, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, least squares

metadata.prerequisites_raw: MATH 150 or 151 or MACM 101, with a minimum grade of C-; or MATH 154 or 157, both with a grade of at least B.

courses.title: Algebra I: Linear Algebra
courses.document:
MATH 240 - Algebra I: Linear Algebra
Department: MATH | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: MATH 150 or 151 or MACM 101, with a minimum grade of C-; or MATH 154 or 157, both with a grade of at least B.

Linear equations, matrices, determinants. Real and abstract vector spaces, subspaces and linear transformations; basis and change of basis. Complex numbers. Eigenvalues and eigenvectors; diagonalization. Inner products and orthogonality; least squares problems. Applications. Subject is presented with an abstract emphasis and includes proofs of the basic theorems.

Good for students interested in: linear equations, matrices, determinants, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, diagonalization, orthogonality

metadata.prerequisites_raw: MATH 150 or 151 or MACM 101, with a minimum grade of C-; or MATH 154 or 157, both with a grade of at least B.

courses.title: Vector/Complex Analysis Apsc
courses.document:
MATH 254 - Vector/Complex Analysis Apsc
Department: MATH | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: MATH 240 or 232, and 251, all with a minimum grade of C-. MATH 240 or 232 may be taken concurrently.

Designed for students in the Engineering Science program. Combines a continuation of the study of vector calculus from MATH 251 with an introduction to functions of a complex variable. Vector functions of a single variable, space curves, scalar and vector fields, conservative fields, surface and volume integrals, and theorems of Gauss, Green and Stokes. Functions of a complex variable, differentiability, contour integrals, Cauchy's theorem. Taylor and Laurent expansion, method of residues, integral transform and conformal mapping.

Good for students interested in: vector calculus, complex analysis, vector fields, scalar fields, contour integrals, cauchy's theorem, taylor and laurent series, conformal mapping

metadata.prerequisites_raw: MATH 240 or 232, and 251, all with a minimum grade of C-. MATH 240 or 232 may be taken concurrently.

courses.title: Industrial Internship I
courses.document:
MSE 293 - Industrial Internship I
Department: MSE | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Off-campus, Other Vancouver | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

First four month internship in industry. Credit is given as pass/withdraw/fail (P/W/F) only, based on the employer's and co-operative education co-ordinator's evaluations. Units from this course do not count towards the units required for an SFU degree.

Good for students interested in: industrial experience, professional skills, workplace communication, industry practices, technical application, project management, teamwork, problem-solving

courses.title: Special Internship I
courses.document:
MSE 294 - Special Internship I
Department: MSE | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Off-campus, Other Vancouver | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

Four month internship in industry or university research environment. Credit is awarded as in MSE 293. Prior approval of Internship Co-ordinator required. Units from this course do not count towards the units required for an SFU degree.

Good for students interested in: industry research, laboratory techniques, experimental methods, data analysis, technical communication, problem solving, materials characterization

courses.title: Introductory Spanish II
courses.document:
SPAN 110 - Introductory Spanish II
Department: SPAN | Level: 100 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Blended
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: SPAN 100 (or SPAN 102), grade 12 Spanish, or equivalent.

Follows SPAN 100. Continues introduction to Spanish for students who have developed the necessary foundations from SPAN 100. Emphasis is on oral skills and grammar while continuing to develop reading and writing proficiency. Practical and situational materials are employed to underline the ties between language and culture. By the end of the term, students will be able to communicate in Spanish using a wide range of grammatical structures and vocabulary. (A2 level of CEFR)

Good for students interested in: spanish grammar, oral communication, reading comprehension, writing proficiency, vocabulary development, cultural context, conversational skills, a2 cefr level

metadata.prerequisites_raw: SPAN 100 (or SPAN 102), grade 12 Spanish, or equivalent.

courses.title: Business Law and Ethics
courses.document:
BUS 233 - Business Law and Ethics
Department: BUS | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: 12 units.

Provides students with the basic legal and ethical principles and frameworks that are necessary when one is operating within a business context. The design of the course combines components of two core courses in the undergraduate business program, namely, Commercial Law (BUS 393) and Business Ethics (BUS 303). This course is not recommended for students admitted to the business administration major.

Good for students interested in: business law, commercial law, business ethics, legal frameworks, ethical decision-making, corporate governance, regulatory compliance, critical thinking

metadata.prerequisites_raw: 12 units.

courses.title: Introduction to Finance
courses.document:
BUS 312 - Introduction to Finance
Department: BUS | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby, Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: BUS 254 and (BUS 232 or ECON 233 or STAT 270 or STAT 271), both with a minimum grade of C- and 45 units; OR actuarial science students with BUS 254 and (BUS 232 or ECON 233 or STAT 270 or STAT 271), b...

An introduction to basic and fundamental concepts in finance. Topics may include: financial statements analysis, time value of money, investment decisions and capital budgeting, income and equity securities and markets, risk and return, asset pricing models, capital market efficiency, capital structure.

Good for students interested in: financial statements analysis, time value of money, investment decisions, capital budgeting, income securities, equity securities, risk and return, asset pricing models

metadata.prerequisites_raw: BUS 254 and (BUS 232 or ECON 233 or STAT 270 or STAT 271), both with a minimum grade of C- and 45 units; OR actuarial science students with BUS 254 and (BUS 232 or ECON 233 or STAT 270 or STAT 271), both with a minimum grade of C- and 45 units. Recommended: BUS 207 or ECON 201.

courses.title: Business Communication
courses.document:
BUS 360W - Business Communication
Department: BUS | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby, Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: W | Prerequisites: This course is open to students admitted to the business administration major, honours, or second degree program and who have 45 units and BUS 130 or (BUS 201 or BUS 202) or BUS 301, and BUS 217W, bot...

Helps students develop professional writing- and speaking-based communication strategies they can confidently adapt to a wide range of business situations. The course aims to raise their communication performance to a professionally acceptable level, rather than to memorize or theorize about communication knowledge: this is a learn-by-doing course. Students will improve their ability to conceptualize, analyze/evaluate, synthesize, and apply information to guide their thinking and finished products across various business contexts. As teamwork is a fundamental skill valued by employers, students will participate in a major team project to learn about and apply best practices for collaboration with respect to professional business communication. The primary means of instruction and learning is guided practice in both writing and presenting in response to realistic business contexts. Instruction and assessment focus on both the process of creating professional, finished products, as well as the quality of those products.

Good for students interested in: business communication, professional writing, oral communication, teamwork collaboration, communication strategies, business presentations, critical thinking, information synthesis

metadata.prerequisites_raw: This course is open to students admitted to the business administration major, honours, or second degree program and who have 45 units and BUS 130 or (BUS 201 or BUS 202) or BUS 301, and BUS 217W, both with a minimum grade of C-, OR to students admitted Fall 2022 onwards to the business administration major, honours, or second degree program, and who have 45 units; BUS 217W and (BUS 201 or BUS 202), both with a minimum grade of C-; and BUS 300, OR to business administration joint major or joint honours students with BUS 217W with a minimum grade of C- and 45 units, OR to business and economics joint major students with ECON 220W with a minimum grade of C- and 45 units, OR to mechatronic systems engineering and business administration double degree students with 45 units, OR to data science major with BUS 217W with a minimum grade of C- and 45 units.

courses.title: Intro Analytical Chemistry
courses.document:
CHEM 210 - Intro Analytical Chemistry
Department: CHEM | Level: 200 | Units: 2
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: CHEM 122 with a minimum grade of C-.

The principles of analytical chemistry and their practical application to solution samples. Titrimetric and electrochemical methods. This course has the same lecture component as CHEM 215 but no laboratory work.

Good for students interested in: analytical chemistry, titrimetry, electrochemical methods, solution analysis, quantitative analysis, chemical instrumentation, data interpretation, chemical equilibria

metadata.prerequisites_raw: CHEM 122 with a minimum grade of C-.

courses.document:
CHEM 286 - Organic Chem Lab II
Department: CHEM | Level: 200 | Units: 2
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: CHEM 281 with a minimum grade of C-. Corequisite: CHEM 282 or 283.

Laboratory work chosen to complement the lecture course.

Good for students interested in: organic synthesis, reaction mechanisms, laboratory techniques, spectroscopy analysis, experimental design, data interpretation, chemical safety, purification methods

metadata.prerequisites_raw: CHEM 281 with a minimum grade of C-. Corequisite: CHEM 282 or 283.

courses.title: Prof. Resp. & Tech. Writing
courses.document:
CMPT 376W - Prof. Resp. & Tech. Writing
Department: CMPT | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby, Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: W | Prerequisites: CMPT 105W and (CMPT 275 or CMPT 276), with a minimum grade of C-.

Covers professional writing in computing science, including format conventions and technical reports. The basis for ethical decision-making and the methodology for reaching ethical decisions concerning computing matters will be studied. Students will survey and write research papers, and both individual and group work will be emphasized.

Good for students interested in: technical writing, professional communication, ethical decision-making, computing ethics, research writing, report formatting, collaborative writing, technical reports

metadata.prerequisites_raw: CMPT 105W and (CMPT 275 or CMPT 276), with a minimum grade of C-.

courses.title: Microeconomic Theory I
courses.document:
ECON 201 - Microeconomic Theory I
Department: ECON | Level: 200 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: ECON 103 with a minimum grade of C- or ECON 113 with a minimum grade of B-; ECON 105 with a minimum grade of C- or ECON 115 with a minimum grade of B-; MATH 150, MATH 151, MATH 154, or MATH 157, with ...

Aspects of microeconomic theory involving competitive markets. Topics include the behavior of households and firms, partial equilibrium analysis of product and factor markets, and general equilibrium.

Good for students interested in: microeconomic theory, competitive markets, household behavior, firm behavior, partial equilibrium analysis, product markets, factor markets, general equilibrium

metadata.prerequisites_raw: ECON 103 with a minimum grade of C- or ECON 113 with a minimum grade of B-; ECON 105 with a minimum grade of C- or ECON 115 with a minimum grade of B-; MATH 150, MATH 151, MATH 154, or MATH 157, with a minimum grade of C-.

courses.title: Intro Labour Econ.
courses.document:
ECON 280 - Intro Labour Econ.
Department: ECON | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: ECON 103 with a minimum grade of C- or ECON 113 with a minimum grade of B-.

Basic analysis of the labor market and the industrial relations system with emphasis on the major issues of public policy in Canada.

Good for students interested in: labor market, industrial relations, public policy, wage determination, employment trends, labor supply and demand, collective bargaining, labor economics

metadata.prerequisites_raw: ECON 103 with a minimum grade of C- or ECON 113 with a minimum grade of B-.

courses.title: Intro to Reflective Practice
courses.document:
EDUC 252 - Intro to Reflective Practice
Department: EDUC | Level: 200 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

Provides opportunities for prospective educators to begin their development as reflective practitioners. Through readings, classroom activities and discussions, and interactions with students and practicing teachers, students will be exposed to various educational issues and questions. They will be given time to explore their own values and beliefs about education and teaching. Time may be spent observing in a selection of educational settings, and there may be opportunities to work with learners individually, and in small and large groups.

Good for students interested in: reflective practice, educational theory, classroom observation, values exploration, teaching philosophy, learner engagement, educational issues, critical reflection

courses.title: Reading Writing Identities
courses.document:
ENGL 210 - Reading Writing Identities
Department: ENGL | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: 12 units or one 100-division English course.

Considers how identity - construed psychologically, culturally, or socially - is performed and interrogated through literature and language. May be further organized by historical period, genre, or critical approach. This course may be repeated for credit if a different topic is taught.

Good for students interested in: identity studies, literary analysis, cultural theory, critical reading, writing skills, social psychology, genre studies, historical context

metadata.prerequisites_raw: 12 units or one 100-division English course.

courses.title: Intermediate French I
courses.document:
FREN 201 - Intermediate French I
Department: FREN | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: Grade 12 French or FREN 102 or FREN 122 or permission of the Department of French.

This is the first of two intermediate level courses in French. Through a variety of original documents in French (descriptive articles, audio-visual interviews and presentations, recorded testimonies from French speakers, ), students will be introduced to francophone cultures and communicative situations related to ones personal environment such as city life, housing, relationships, education and work. A strong focus will be made on the development of listening skills and oral production, as well as reading and writing. Grammar will be introduced and practiced mostly online with only short review sessions in class. It will cover present, past and future tenses as well as some basic sentence structures. Classes will be taught entirely in French and students will be expected to communicate in French.

Good for students interested in: intermediate french, francophone cultures, listening skills, oral production, reading comprehension, writing skills, french grammar, communicative situations

metadata.prerequisites_raw: Grade 12 French or FREN 102 or FREN 122 or permission of the Department of French.

courses.title: Multimedia Program Art/Design
courses.document:
IAT 265 - Multimedia Program Art/Design
Department: IAT | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: IAT 167 with a minimum grade of C- and one of MATH 130, MACM 101, MATH 150, MATH 151, MATH 154, or MATH 157, with a minimum grade of C-.

Using cases from topics such as animation, cinema, music and design, this course introduces a variety of programming tools and techniques. Practical use of multimedia scripting languages and authoring environments is covered in the context of a series of composition and design projects. Code libraries and programming techniques for specific media will be introduced. Assessment will be based on both programming and the expressive use of programs in their case context.

Good for students interested in: animation, multimedia scripting, programming techniques, multimedia authoring environments, code libraries, media design, digital composition, expressive programming

metadata.prerequisites_raw: IAT 167 with a minimum grade of C- and one of MATH 130, MACM 101, MATH 150, MATH 151, MATH 154, or MATH 157, with a minimum grade of C-.

courses.title: Description Analysis INLG II
courses.document:
INLG 234 - Description Analysis INLG II
Department: INLG | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Off-campus | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

A continuation of the intermediate course in an Indigenous language, including writing systems, texts, general linguistic properties, and language family. Based on a designated language and usually chosen from the Northwest Coast area. Students may retake this course with focus on a different Indigenous language.

Good for students interested in: indigenous languages, writing systems, linguistic properties, language families, text analysis, descriptive linguistics, northwest coast languages, language documentation

metadata.prerequisites_raw: INLG (or FNLG) 233.

courses.title: INLG Immersion II: Language
courses.document:
INLG 258 - INLG Immersion II: Language
Department: INLG | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Off-campus | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

Intensive language instruction in an Indigenous language at an intermediate level. The course will be based on a designated language to be named each time it is taught. Please inquire at Indigenous Languages Program (inlp@sfu.ca) for information on placement.

Good for students interested in: indigenous languages, language immersion, intermediate language skills, language proficiency, cultural linguistics, language acquisition, oral communication, linguistic competence

courses.title: Linguistics in the Real World
courses.document:
LING 280 - Linguistics in the Real World
Department: LING | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Blended
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

Examines real-world issues from a linguistic perspective. Topics may range across a wide spectrum: in-depth analysis of specific languages, social issues (stereotypes, inequality), business matters (linguistics in advertising, legal language), the role of linguistics in the technology sector, as well as more general workplace applications for linguistics. As topics examined may vary by term, this course may be repeated once for credit if the topic is different. Open to all students.

Good for students interested in: sociolinguistics, language and society, discourse analysis, language and inequality, applied linguistics, legal language, linguistic anthropology, language in technology

courses.title: Industrial Internship I
courses.document:
SEE 290 - Industrial Internship I
Department: SEE | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Off-campus, Other Vancouver | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

The first of 3 term-long work placements in which students gain real-world experience in research or industrial facilities, often designing and building real products. Students integrate theory and practice as a student engineer. Students are supported to prepare their job search strategies, conduct professional interviews and explore and develop their career goals. Units from this course do not count towards the units required for an SFU degree.

Good for students interested in: industrial internship, engineering practice, product design, real-world experience, professional skills, job search strategies, interview preparation, career development

courses.title: Special Internship I
courses.document:
SEE 294 - Special Internship I
Department: SEE | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Off-campus, Other Vancouver | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

An alternative experience to a regular co-op work term. This may include, but is not restricted to, a self-directed project (eg. sustainable community project), service (eg. intern with Engineers Without Borders), entrepreneurial, or research terms. Prior approval of the Internship Coordinator is required. To be granted credit Special Internship I must meet the regular criteria for a co-op work term. Units from this course do not count towards the units required for an SFU degree.

Good for students interested in: self-directed projects, sustainable community development, service learning, entrepreneurship, research methods, project management, community engagement, professional communication

courses.title: Experiment/Observational Data
courses.document:
STAT 302 - Experiment/Observational Data
Department: STAT | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online, In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: One of STAT 201, STAT 203, STAT 205, STAT 270, BUS 232, or ECON 233, with a minimum grade of C-.

The standard techniques of multiple regression analysis, analysis of variance, and analysis of covariance, and their role in observational and experimental studies. This course may not be used to satisfy the upper division requirements of the following programs: statistics major, statistics honours, actuarial science major, and actuarial science honours.

Good for students interested in: multiple regression, analysis of variance, analysis of covariance, experimental design, observational studies, statistical inference, data analysis, hypothesis testing

metadata.prerequisites_raw: One of STAT 201, STAT 203, STAT 205, STAT 270, BUS 232, or ECON 233, with a minimum grade of C-.

courses.title: Cultural Heritage Management
courses.document:
ARCH 286 - Cultural Heritage Management
Department: ARCH | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: 30 units including one of ARCH 100, ARCH 101, ARCH 201, EVSC 100, GEOG 100, or REM 100.

Examines cultural heritage management as the universal process by which people use places, objects and traditions from the past to educate, entertain, profit, promote change, maintain status quo, create identities, and build communities and nations. The course presents archaeology as one aspect of cultural heritage management and as an activity governed by national laws and international conventions for protecting and making appropriate use of heritage. Using case studies from Canada and abroad, the course explores stewardship as a fundamental professional ethic in archaeology and other fields engaged in studying, applying, and safeguarding personal, familial, communal, national, and transnational heritage.

Good for students interested in: cultural heritage management, archaeology, heritage conservation, stewardship ethics, cultural identity, heritage law, international heritage conventions, case study analysis

metadata.prerequisites_raw: 30 units including one of ARCH 100, ARCH 101, ARCH 201, EVSC 100, GEOG 100, or REM 100.

courses.title: Ancient Visual Art
courses.document:
ARCH 301 - Ancient Visual Art
Department: ARCH | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: 45 credit hours.

A selection of major art traditions from Africa, Asia, Europe, North America, Mesoamerica and South America is explored. Issues of intellectual property rights, copyright and the use of ancient art in contemporary contexts are also addressed.

Good for students interested in: ancient art, art traditions, intellectual property rights, copyright, cultural heritage, visual analysis, art history, cross-cultural studies

metadata.prerequisites_raw: 45 credit hours.

courses.title: Entrepreneurship & Innovation
courses.document:
BUS 238 - Entrepreneurship & Innovation
Department: BUS | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: 12 units.

Students will build collaborative and creative skills necessary to become effective innovators through hands-on application via interdisciplinary teamwork. Entrepreneurship and innovation of all types will be addressed including social, commercial, creative, sustainable and technological perspectives.

Good for students interested in: entrepreneurship, innovation, creative problem solving, interdisciplinary teamwork, social entrepreneurship, sustainable innovation, technological innovation, collaborative skills

metadata.prerequisites_raw: 12 units.

courses.title: Intro Analytical Chem Lab
courses.document:
CHEM 216 - Intro Analytical Chem Lab
Department: CHEM | Level: 200 | Units: 2
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: CHEM 122 and CHEM 126, both with a minimum grade of C-. Corequisite: CHEM 210.

Experiments in analytical chemistry, including analysis of solution samples, titrimetric and electroanalytical methods. This course has the same laboratory component as CHEM 215.

Good for students interested in: analytical chemistry, titrimetric analysis, electroanalytical methods, solution analysis, quantitative analysis, laboratory techniques, chemical experimentation, data interpretation

metadata.prerequisites_raw: CHEM 122 and CHEM 126, both with a minimum grade of C-. Corequisite: CHEM 210.

courses.title: Organic Chemistry IIb
courses.document:
CHEM 283 - Organic Chemistry IIb
Department: CHEM | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: CHEM 281 with a minimum grade of C-.

An advanced treatment of Organic Chemistry II. Topics include dienes and their reactivity, conjugation and aromaticity, aromatic substitution reactions, carboxylic acids and their derivatives, ketones and aldehydes, biological molecules, radical reactions, organometallic reagents, pericyclic reactions and planning multi-step synthesis.

Good for students interested in: dienes, aromaticity, aromatic substitution, carboxylic acids, ketones, radical reactions, organometallic reagents, multi-step synthesis

metadata.prerequisites_raw: CHEM 281 with a minimum grade of C-.

courses.title: Electric Circuits I
courses.document:
ENSC 220 - Electric Circuits I
Department: ENSC | Level: 200 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: (PHYS 121 or PHYS 126 or PHYS 141), ENSC 120, MATH 232 and (MATH 260 or MATH 310), all with a minimum grade of C-. MATH 260 may be taken concurrently.

Fundamental electrical circuit quantities, and circuit elements; circuits laws such as Ohm law, Kirchoff's voltage and current laws, along with series and parallel circuits; operational amplifiers; network theorems; nodal and mesh methods; analysis of natural and step response of first (RC and RL), as well as second order (RLC) circuits; real, reactive and rms power concepts. In addition, the course will discuss the worker safety implications of both electricity and common laboratory practices such as soldering.

Good for students interested in: electrical circuits, ohm's law, kirchhoff's laws, operational amplifiers, network theorems, nodal and mesh analysis, transient response, power concepts

metadata.prerequisites_raw: (PHYS 121 or PHYS 126 or PHYS 141), ENSC 120, MATH 232 and (MATH 260 or MATH 310), all with a minimum grade of C-. MATH 260 may be taken concurrently.

courses.title: Academic in FASS
courses.document:
FASS 222 - Academic in FASS
Department: FASS | Level: 200 | Units: 1
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

Introduces the basic knowledge and skills required for producing accurate, responsible, and effective academic work in the arts and social sciences. Topics vary with instructor expertise. No prior knowledge of the topic is required. Suitable for students across all disciplines, but designed for students in the arts and social sciences. Students may take this course for credit up to three times if a different topic is taught. Grading will be on a pass/fail basis.

Good for students interested in: academic writing, research methods, critical thinking, argumentation, arts and social sciences, source evaluation, effective communication, academic integrity

courses.title: Find a Career - Arts & Soc Sci
courses.document:
FASS 223 - Find a Career - Arts & Soc Sci
Department: FASS | Level: 200 | Units: 1
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

Introduces the basic knowledge and skills for FASS students to better adapt and deploy their academics expertise in the workplace. Topics vary with instructor expertise. No prior knowledge of the topic is required. Suitable for students across all disciplines, but designed for students in the arts and social sciences. Students may take this course for credit up to three times if a different topic is taught. Grading will be on a pass/fail basis.

Good for students interested in: career planning, transferable skills, workplace adaptation, academic skills application, communication skills, critical thinking, interdisciplinary studies, professional development

courses.title: Arts & Soc Sci Everyday Life
courses.document:
FASS 224 - Arts & Soc Sci Everyday Life
Department: FASS | Level: 200 | Units: 1
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

Introduces ways in which FASS expertise directly informs everyday personal and social issues and challenges. Topics vary with instructor expertise. No prior knowledge of the topic is required. Suitable for students across all disciplines. Students may take this course for credit up to three times if a different topic is taught. Grading will be on a pass/fail basis.

Good for students interested in: social issues, personal identity, cultural analysis, interdisciplinary studies, critical thinking, social dynamics, everyday life, qualitative research

courses.title: Geog Natural Hazards
courses.document:
GEOG 312 - Geog Natural Hazards
Department: GEOG | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: One of GEOG 100, 104 or 111 or one of EASC 101 or 104.

An exploration of human response to our hazardous Earth. The dynamic causes of natural hazards such as earthquakes, hurricanes, landslides and floods will be illustrated. Students will gain an appreciation for how humans perceive, predict, and recover from hazards and how their effects may be reduced.

Good for students interested in: natural hazards, earthquake dynamics, hurricane impact, landslide processes, flood management, hazard prediction, risk assessment, disaster recovery

courses.title: Workers in the Global Economy
courses.document:
LBST 201 - Workers in the Global Economy
Department: LBST | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: Strongly Recommended: LBST 101.

Explores how people experience paid and unpaid work in the global economy. Focuses on processes such as migration and economic structuring, and applies critical development studies and critical geopolitics to study labour and employment. Explores links between capitalism, urbanization and labour struggles. Examines labour internationalism and global labour rights.

Good for students interested in: global economy, labour studies, migration, economic structuring, critical development studies, critical geopolitics, labour internationalism, global labour rights

metadata.prerequisites_raw: Strongly Recommended: LBST 101.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person

Measurement of interest, present value. Equations of value. Annuities. Loans and amortization schedules. Bonds and other securities. Cash flows: yield rates, duration, convexity, immunization. Yield curves: spot rates, forward rates. Interest rate swaps.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

courses.document:
BUS 272 - Behaviour in Organizations
Department: BUS | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby, Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: 12 units.

Theories, concepts and issues in the field of organizational behaviour with an emphasis on individual and team processes. Core topics include employee motivation and performance, stress management, communication, work perceptions and attitudes, decision-making, team dynamics, employee involvement and conflict management.

Good for students interested in: organizational behaviour, employee motivation, stress management, communication, decision-making, team dynamics, conflict management, work attitudes

courses.title: Business in a Sustainable Soc.
courses.document:
BUS 275 - Business in a Sustainable Soc.
Department: BUS | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby, Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: 12 units.

Businesses and business leaders have a key role to play in supporting a sustainable future. In this course, we examine what it means to be a responsible business and how businesses can do their part to be a catalyst for system-level change. We will also consider our own roles in supporting the necessary transition to a more regenerative and reconciled economy.

Good for students interested in: sustainable business, corporate social responsibility, system-level change, regenerative economy, ethical leadership, business strategy, environmental sustainability, social impact

Investments from an individual and institutional point of view. Topics include: bond valuation and the term structure of interest rates, stock valuation, portfolio theory, asset pricing models, efficient markets and introduction to derivative securities.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person

An examination of a range of theories of everyday language focused on specific forms of discursive practice, including gossip, humour, religion, and sarcasm.

metadata.prerequisites_raw: 17 CMNS units with a minimum grade of C- or 45 units with a minimum CGPA of 2.00.

Campus: Burnaby, Surrey | Delivery: In Person

An overview of various techniques used for software development and software project management. Major tasks and phases in modern software development, including requirements, analysis, documentation, design, implementation, testing,and maintenance. Project management issues are also introduced. Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person

Analysis of theories of economic development. Consideration will be given to the requirements of successful development, to aspects of international co-operation, and to procedures of economic planning. Problems of emerging countries and models of various developing economies will be studied.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online, In Person
WQB: W | Prerequisites: EDUC 252.

Building on the experience of EDUC 252, prospective educators will continue to develop their reflective practice. Various educational issues related to the caring for learners and the creation of learning communities will be explored. Students will spend time in educational settings exploring the importance of connected educational experiences for learners.

Good for students interested in: reflective practice, educational issues, learner care, learning communities, experiential learning, educational settings, connected learning, professional development

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

Introduces students to the historical and contemporary contexts of treaty relations between settlers and the First Peoples of Turtle Island. Provides critical insight into the various treaties within Canada; treaty negotiations, including Indigenous oral histories; Indigenous resistance to treaty infringements; and other important legislation impacting treaty rights.

Good for students interested in: treaty relations, indigenous oral histories, treaty negotiations, indigenous resistance, canadian legislation, treaty rights, historical contexts, contemporary issues

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person

Campus: Burnaby, Surrey | Delivery: In Person

An introduction to key innovation concepts and processes, and how innovation is organized in established organizations and start-ups. Students will learn their role as agents of innovation by practicing techniques that help them anticipate opportunities, generate innovative concepts, and implement innovation in established organizations, entrepreneurial ventures and society.

Good for students interested in: innovation management, creativity techniques, opportunity recognition, entrepreneurial ventures, organizational innovation, idea generation, innovation processes, strategic implementation

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

Basic knowledge of the underlying principles and concepts of the Canadian Income Tax Act and the application of its rules to practical situations. It also examines the general income tax planning principles and equips students with the ability to identify tax planning opportunities for individuals.

Good for students interested in: canadian income tax act, income tax principles, tax planning strategies, individual taxation, tax compliance, tax law application, financial decision-making, tax regulations

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person

Investigate data analytics, visualization, and modeling approaches relevant to business decisions. The course will investigate three important pillars of analytics including decision analytics, predictive analytics, and data visualization.

Laboratory component that builds upon the concepts covered in Chemistry 110. Designed for students with limited or no background in chemistry, the laboratory environment allows students to put fundamental concepts into practice. Laboratory skills include safety, handling chemicals, and studying chemical reactions and their products. No previous training in chemistry is required for this course.

Elements of physical chemistry from the macroscopic point of view. Thermodynamics, and its applications to chemical equilibrium. Chemical kinetics and reaction rate theories.

COGS 200 - Foundations Cognitive Science
Department: COGS | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: COGS 100.

An introduction to major empirical methods and theoretical frameworks for exploring the mind that examines some of the foundational debates that have fueled investigations over the past fifty years. Taking an interdisciplinary approach, the course illustrates how a convergence of ideas from psychology, philosophy, linguistics, and computer science has led to deep explanations of a range of cognitive science topics.

Good for students interested in: cognitive science, empirical methods, theoretical frameworks, interdisciplinary approaches, psychology, philosophy, linguistics, computer science

metadata.prerequisites_raw: COGS 100.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Blended
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: CRIM 101; one of CRIM 120 or 220; one of STAT 201, 203, 205, BUS 232, or PSYC 210. CRIM 320 may be taken concurrently with CRIM 321.

A detailed examination of the quantitative research methods and techniques most frequently used in criminological research. Advantages and shortcomings of each method and the appropriateness of each technique for criminological research. Problems of pure and applied research. Specific issues of interdisciplinary research are discussed.

Good for students interested in: quantitative research methods, statistical analysis, criminological research, research design, data collection techniques, interdisciplinary research, applied research, research methodology

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: EDUC 401/402 or corequisite EDUC 403.

Conceptions of numeracy in contemporary society; consequences of innumeracy; enhancing personal numeracy skills; examination of numeracy across the curriculum. This course is designed for students NOT working in a Mathematics or Science specialization.

Good for students interested in: numeracy, innumeracy, personal numeracy skills, numeracy across curriculum, quantitative literacy, mathematical reasoning, societal impact of numeracy, critical thinking

courses.title: Literacy, Education, Culture
courses.document:
EDUC 341 - Literacy, Education, Culture
Department: EDUC | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: 60 units including three units in EDUC courses.

What counts as literacy and whose literacies are valued? What does this mean for the organization of societies, and for teaching and learning? How is literacy implicated in projects of social ordering, colonialism, oppression and empowerment? This course explores these questions through case studies, histories, policies and place-based investigations of literacy education across the life course and inside and outside formal schooling.

Good for students interested in: literacy theories, cultural literacy, critical pedagogy, social justice education, literacy policy analysis, colonialism and education, educational equity, qualitative research methods

metadata.prerequisites_raw: 60 units including three units in EDUC courses.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: BC Math 12 (or equivalent, or any of MATH 100, 150, 151, 154, or 157, with a minimum grade of C-).

An introduction to software development for students in engineering and related programs covering theory and practicum of software design, testing, and debugging. This includes basic C++ programming language elements such as basic types, variables, expressions, statements, exception handling, functions, simple classes, and an introduction to the C++ standard library.

Good for students interested in: software design, software testing, debugging, c++ programming, exception handling, functions, classes, standard library

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person

Lecture topics include but not limited to: basics of computer systems, abstraction between hardware and software (using modern RISC-V instruction set), fundamentals of processor design and cache memory hierarchy design, and recent trends of parallel computing and domain-specific computing. ENSC 254 is a mandatory course for all engineering science options.

metadata.prerequisites_raw: ENSC 251 and ENSC 252, both with a minimum grade of C-.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Soc | Prerequisites: 60 units.

Examination of the aging process from a multi-disciplinary perspective. Physical and health factors in aging, economic and vocational factors in aging, family and community relations of older people, social policy and politics of aging. Throughout the course, emphasis will be placed on normative age-related changes.

metadata.prerequisites_raw: 60 units.

Principles and applications in health sciences research methodology. Quantitative and qualitative methods. Research process and design. Appropriate approaches for diverse research questions. Research ethics, sources of data, sampling, measurement, data collection, initial data analysis techniques.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Blended
WQB: None | Prerequisites: PSYC 102.

An introduction to the area of law and psychology. The role and influence of psychology in the legal system will be discussed. Topics include: social psychology and law, developmental psychology and law, juvenile justice, experimental psychology and law, mental disability and law.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: W | Prerequisites: 60 units.

Explores the formulation and analysis of marketing goals within the evolving realm of online promotion and marketing. Emphasis is given to approaches to measurement of effect; implementation and campaign management; finding and nurturing audiences and conversations; branding; forecasting and budgeting.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: W | Prerequisites: 45 units. Philosophy Majors and Minors may not take this course for credit towards their major or minor degree.

An introduction to the field of environmental ethics. Addresses questions such as what obligations we have to future generations and the natural world, as well as the extent of these obligations.

courses.title: Intro to Prob/Stat for CompSci
courses.document:
STAT 271 - Intro to Prob/Stat for CompSci
Department: STAT | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: CMPT 210 with a minimum grade of C-.

This is an introductory course in probability and statistics that is designed for Computer Science students. Mainly covers basic probability theory and statistical methods for designing and analyzing computing algorithms and systems. Topics include continuous probability distributions, random variables, multivariate normal distributions, parameter estimation and inference theory, as well as design and analysis of statistical studies, including hypothesis testing and presentation of statistical data.

Good for students interested in: probability theory, statistical methods, continuous probability distributions, random variables, parameter estimation, inference theory, hypothesis testing, data presentation

courses.document:
BISC 202 - Genetics
Department: BISC | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: BISC 101 and 102, both with a minimum grade of C-.

Principles and concepts of transmission of genetic information. Topics include: molecular basis of inheritance, interpretation of pedigrees, chromosomal mapping, linkage, crosses, epigenetics, and the regulation and flow of genetic information from DNA to proteins. Focus on problem-solving.

Good for students interested in: genetics, molecular inheritance, pedigree analysis, chromosomal mapping, genetic linkage, epigenetics, gene regulation, problem-solving

metadata.prerequisites_raw: BISC 101 and 102, both with a minimum grade of C-.

courses.title: Active Health
courses.document:
BPK 343 - Active Health
Department: BPK | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: BPK 142, 143 and 205; STAT 201 or an equivalent statistics course, BPK 340 (may be taken concurrently). Students must successfully complete a Criminal Record Check prior to enrolling.

An extension of BPK 143, Exercise: Health and Performance, designed to provide students with an opportunity to appreciate principles of exercise leadership, assess individual fitness needs, design programs and monitor effects of prescribed exercise. The course includes a 34 hour unpaid practicum with an industry partner. The partner may require the student to enter into (1) a confidentiality agreement and (2) an Intellectual property agreement the result of which will be that the SFU Intellectual Policy R 30.03 will not apply to the intellectual property created by the student during the practicum. By registering for the course, each student acknowledges that it is aware of these requirements and understands that their entering into these agreements may be a requirement to complete the applicable course work.

Good for students interested in: exercise leadership, fitness assessment, program design, exercise monitoring, health performance, practicum experience, physical activity principles, exercise prescription

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: CMNS 110 or 130, with a minimum grade of C-.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: (CMPT 125 or CMPT 135) and MACM 101, both with a minimum grade of C-.

An introduction to a UNIX-like application-OS interface from a programmer's perspective. Introduces operating systems and their interfaces for user-level programs. Students learn how to programmatically interact with an OS efficiently, correctly, and securely. Topics include: command-line tools, programming with memory, processes, threads, IPC, as well as basics of OS security.

Good for students interested in: operating systems, unix interface, system calls, process management, multithreading, interprocess communication, memory management, os security

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: MACM 101, MATH 152, CMPT 125 or CMPT 135, and (MATH 240 or MATH 232), all with a minimum grade of C-.

Probability has become an essential tool in modern computer science with applications in randomized algorithms, computer vision and graphics, systems, data analysis, and machine learning. The course introduces the foundational concepts in probability as required by many modern applications in computing.

Good for students interested in: probability theory, randomized algorithms, data analysis, machine learning, computer vision, computer graphics, systems, foundational probability concepts

courses.title: Object Oriented Design in Java
courses.document:
CMPT 213 - Object Oriented Design in Java
Department: CMPT | Level: 200 | Units: 3
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: CMPT 225 with a minimum grade of C-.

An introduction to object oriented design using Java. The Java programming language is introduced, with an emphasis on its advanced features. The course covers the building blocks of object oriented design including inheritance, polymorphism, interfaces and abstract classes. A number of object oriented design patterns are presented, such as observer, iterator, and singleton. The course also teaches best-practices in code construction. It includes a basic introduction to programming event driven graphical user interfaces.

Good for students interested in: object oriented design, java programming, inheritance, polymorphism, interfaces, design patterns, event driven programming, graphical user interfaces

Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: CMPT 125 or CMPT 135, with a minimum grade of C-.

Surveys contemporary Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) topics on designing, implementing, and evaluating interactive computer systems from a human-centered perspective. Students will learn important concepts including understanding users, incorporating accountability and responsibility in design, creating accessible and inclusive systems, and evaluating system interfaces with well-established methodologies.

Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: B-Hum | Prerequisites: 60 units.

An exploration of Indigenous knowledges, languages, and cultures from the geographic region that is currently known as Canada with a specific focus on what is currently British Columbia. Considerations and implications for teaching practices in educational environments will also be explored.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: W | Prerequisites: 60 units; or permission of instructor.

Explores health concepts, health behaviors, and health concerns of school-aged children and youth. Focuses on comprehensive and co-ordinated school health programs, innovative instructional strategies, and health-promotion initiatives to create healthy school communities.

Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: Q | Prerequisites: EDUC 401/402 or corequisite EDUC 403.

Causes of Mathematics risk and anxiety from both a conceptual and a dispositional point of view. Exploration of different remediation strategies. Enhancement of personal mathematical skills through immersion in a problem-solving environment. The role of mathematical competence in society and job market. This course is designed for prospective secondary teachers not working in a Mathematics or Science specialization. As such, students with sufficient credit to receive a minor in Mathematics, Physics, Biology or Chemistry will not receive credit for this course.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

Students will explore leadership within education institutions, including both formal and informal leadership experiences. courses.title: Foundations of Acad. Literacy
courses.document:
FAL X99 - Foundations of Acad. Literacy
Department: FAL | Level: 0 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

An introduction to the kinds of reading and writing students will encounter in lower division courses across the university disciplines. Important aspects of the writing process are discussed and illustrated in class, and students receive individual feedback on their academic writing. Students who take this class will be graded using a Competency Based grading system (Pass/Fail). Students who wish to use the course to meet the language proficiency prerequisite of a writing-intensive course must obtain a P (equivalent to a C or better). Enrollment priority is given to undergraduate students who have not yet met the language proficiency prerequisite of a writing-intensive course. Students who receive an F grade on their first attempt at the course may re-enroll. No student may attempt the course more than twice. Units from this course count toward the units required for an SFU degree. The offering of this course is for credit.

Good for students interested in: academic writing, reading comprehension, writing process, critical thinking, academic literacy, writing feedback, language proficiency, competency-based assessment

courses.title: STT-JEDI Pract. Life Settings

FASS 305 - STT-JEDI Pract. Life Settings
Department: FASS | Level: 300 | Units: 1
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: None

Explore topics in justice, equity, diversity, and inclusion (JEDI) and their application in workplace, educational, and social settings. The primary objective will be to present the scholarship that has informed JEDI principles in an accessible way and to have you envision applying these in practical life settings. Students will have opportunities to reflect on core JEDI and adjacent concepts. Students may take this course for credit up to three times if a different topic is taught. Grading will be on a pass/fail basis.

Good for students interested in: justice, equity, diversity, inclusion, social justice theory, critical reflection, applied ethics, organizational culture

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person

Through an examination of the social construction of numbers and other forms of quantitative data will provide an introduction to measurement and its use within social justice movements and policy circles. Exploration of the cultural and intellectual accomplishments of a specific city that achieved prominence in a particular time period, and had substantial impact and influence on human civilization. Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: BISC 101 and 102, both with a minimum grade of C-, and completion of less than 60 units; or permission of the instructor.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: BPK 142.

Campus: Burnaby, Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: 45 units.

Examines the context of business in society and the paradigms, frameworks, and theories that shape how we think about business ethics and make ethical decisions. Incorporates recent cross-disciplinary research in the development of reflective practice, moral literacy, and decision-making under conditions of uncertainty, ambiguity, complexity, and diverse competing interests.

Good for students interested in: business ethics, ethical decision-making, moral literacy, reflective practice, ethical frameworks, complexity in business, societal impact of business, interdisciplinary research

Campus: Burnaby, Off-campus | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: BUS 254 with a minimum grade of C-, 45 units.

In-depth examination of important managerial accounting topics introduced in BUS 254 (e.g., transfer pricing, variance analysis) and more advanced topics (e.g., decision making under uncertainty, the value of information), focusing on providing the tools and techniques needed for the generation, analysis and dissemination of management accounting information necessary for making strategic business decisions. The course will also introduce and develop the case approach in order to prepare students for BUS 424.

Good for students interested in: managerial accounting, transfer pricing, variance analysis, decision making under uncertainty, value of information, strategic business decisions, management accounting information, case study analysis

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Blended, In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: 17 CMNS units with a minimum grade of C- or 45 units with a minimum CGPA of 2.00.

Topics pertain to issues of inequality, resistance and activism with a focus on entanglements with media and communication. Explores how relations of power are shaped and contested through media and communication. Topics include: racial justice, environmental policies, globalization, social activism, and labour. This course can be repeated twice for credit if the topics are different (up to a maximum of three times).

Department: BISC | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: BISC 202 with a minimum grade of C-. Recommended: BISC 204.

The phenomenon of organic evolution, and the major processes leading to changes in allele frequencies over time, namely mutation, migration, genetic drift and natural selection. Topics include evolutionary genetics, adaptation, sexual selection, the origin of life, speciation, and the major evolutionary trends over geological time.

Good for students interested in: evolutionary genetics, natural selection, genetic drift, mutation, migration, adaptation, speciation, evolutionary trends

Embryonic and post-embryonic development of vertebrates, invertebrates, and plants, with a focus on both classical and modern experimental approaches. Common and distinct features of the genes and signalling pathways that control development will be compared at the organismal, cellular, molecular and genetic levels.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: CMPT 225 and STAT 271, all with a minimum grade of C-. Recommended: MATH 251.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: CRIM 101. Recommended: CRIM 241

Department: MBB | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: MBB 231, and BISC 202, with a minimum grade of C.

The study of DNA and RNA in relation to gene structure and expression: DNA replication and the regulation of gene expression in bacteria and higher organisms. Introduction to recombinant DNA and cloning theory; natural vector structures and recombinant vector construction.

Good for students interested in: dna replication, gene expression regulation, recombinant dna technology, cloning theory, molecular genetics, vector construction, rna biology, bacterial genetics

metadata.prerequisites_raw: MBB 231, and BISC 202, with a minimum grade of C.

courses.title: Introduction to MEMS
courses.document:
MSE 311 - Introduction to MEMS
Department: MSE | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: MSE 222 (or ENSC 282), MSE 251 (or ENSC 226).

An introduction to microelectromechanical systems, covering thin film processing technologies, bulk and surface micromachining, and MEMS applications.

Good for students interested in: microelectromechanical systems, thin film processing, bulk micromachining, surface micromachining, mems applications, microfabrication techniques, materials characterization, device integration

metadata.prerequisites_raw: MSE 222 (or ENSC 282), MSE 251 (or ENSC 226).

courses.title: Mechatronics Design II
courses.document:
MSE 312 - Mechatronics Design II
Department: MSE | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: MSE 110 (or ENSC 182), MSE 320 (or ENSC 382), MSE 381 (or ENSC 383). MSE 381 may be taken concurrently.

Interweaves mechanisms, electronics, sensors, and control strategies with software and information technology to examine the demands and ideas of customers and find the most efficient, cost-effective method to transform their goals into successful commercial products. Most of the term is devoted to a significant design project in which student groups work independently and competitively, applying the design process to a project goal set by the faculty co-ordinator.

Good for students interested in: mechatronics design, control systems, sensors integration, electronics, software development, product design, systems engineering, design project management

metadata.prerequisites_raw: MSE 110 (or ENSC 182), MSE 320 (or ENSC 382), MSE 381 (or ENSC 383). MSE 381 may be taken concurrently.

courses.title: Power Electronics & Machinery
courses.document:
MSE 353 - Power Electronics & Machinery
Department: MSE | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: MSE 251 (previously ENSC 226).

3-phase circuits, power quality, and transformers, Characteristic of power semiconductor devices, Line frequency controlled rectifiers, Buck, boost, and buck-boost dc-dc power converters, Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) techniques, Voltage source inverters and full-bridge topology, Introduction to dc machines, Introduction to stepper motors, Introduction to induction motors, Introduction to synchronous machines.

Good for students interested in: 3-phase circuits, power semiconductor devices, dc-dc power converters, pulse width modulation, voltage source inverters, transformers, dc machines, induction motors

metadata.prerequisites_raw: MSE 251 (previously ENSC 226).

courses.title: Feedback Control
courses.document:
MSE 381 - Feedback Control
Department: MSE | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: MSE 280 (or ENSC 380).

This course is an introduction to the analysis, design, and applications of continuous time linear control systems. Topics include transfer function representation of open and closed loop systems, time domain specifications and steady state error, sensitivity analysis, time and frequency response, and stability criteria. It includes a treatment of methods for the analysis of control systems based on the root locus, Bode plots and Nyquist criterion, and their use in the design of PID, and lead-lag compensation. Lab work is included in this course.

Good for students interested in: linear control systems, transfer functions, stability analysis, root locus, frequency response, pid control, lead-lag compensation, system design

metadata.prerequisites_raw: MSE 280 (or ENSC 380).

courses.title: Industrial Internship II
courses.document:
MSE 393 - Industrial Internship II
Department: MSE | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Off-campus, Other Vancouver | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: MSE 293 or 294.

Second four month internship in industry. Credit is awarded as in MSE 293. Units from this course do not count towards the units required for an SFU degree.

Campus: Off-campus, Other Vancouver | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: MSE 293 or 294 and approval of internship co-ordinator required.

Four month internship in industry or university research environment. Credit is awarded as in MSE 293. Units from this course do not count towards the units required for an SFU degree.

Good for students interested in: research methods, industry experience, laboratory skills, data analysis, technical communication, problem solving, experimental techniques

metadata.prerequisites_raw: MSE 293 or 294 and approval of internship co-ordinator required.

courses.title: Devl.Psychopathology
courses.document:
PSYC 356 - Devl.Psychopathology
Department: PSYC | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: PSYC 201, 241 and 250.

Examines theoretical approaches, research findings, and treatment outlooks concerning problems and disorders in childhood development.

Good for students interested in: developmental psychopathology, childhood disorders, theoretical approaches, research methods, treatment strategies, child development, psychological assessment, mental health

courses.title: Developmental Disabilities
courses.document:
PSYC 359 - Developmental Disabilities
Department: PSYC | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: None | Prerequisites: PSYC 201 and PSYC 250 (or PSYC 241).

Developmental disorders and disabilities. Topics include genes and environment, peer and parent-child relationships, social attitudes, diversity, ethical issues, and behavioural therapies.

Good for students interested in: developmental disorders, genetic influences, environmental factors, parent-child relationships, social attitudes, behavioural therapies, diversity, ethical issues

metadata.prerequisites_raw: PSYC 201 and PSYC 250 (or PSYC 241).

courses.title: Individual Differences
courses.document:
PSYC 361 - Individual Differences
Department: PSYC | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: PSYC 201, 260.

Predicting peoples thoughts, feelings, behaviour, and happiness is complicated  it largely depends on peoples unique personality characteristics, beliefs, expectations, and motivations. Students will learn about the development and consequences of key individual differences in social psychology.

Good for students interested in: individual differences, personality psychology, social psychology, motivation, beliefs, expectations, behavior prediction, psychological assessment

courses.title: Psychology and Sustainability
courses.document:
PSYC 366 - Psychology and Sustainability
Department: PSYC | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: PSYC 201 and PSYC 260.

A survey of some of the ways that psychological theorizing and research, and social psychology in particular, can be applied to environmental sustainability. Introduces students to some of the environmental challenges faced by contemporary humans and the psychological implications of those challenges.

Good for students interested in: environmental psychology, sustainability, social psychology, behavior change, environmental challenges, psychological research, pro-environmental behavior, attitude formation

metadata.prerequisites_raw: PSYC 201 and PSYC 260.

courses.title: Psychology and Human Sexuality
courses.document:
PSYC 367 - Psychology and Human Sexuality
Department: PSYC | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: None | Prerequisites: PSYC 201, PSYC 260, PSYC 362.

Examines human sexuality from a psychological perspective. Focuses on the empirical research on a variety of topics such as gender differences in sexuality, sexual orientation, models of sexual arousal, erotica, the interplay between sexual and relationship functioning, sexual problems and treatment.

Good for students interested in: human sexuality, sexual orientation, gender differences, sexual arousal, relationship functioning, sexual problems, empirical research, psychological models

metadata.prerequisites_raw: PSYC 201, PSYC 260, PSYC 362.

courses.title: Intervention
courses.document:
PSYC 371 - Intervention
Department: PSYC | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: PSYC 201 and 241.

Reviews the major approaches to psychological intervention in terms of theory, practice and outcome evaluation. The course will examine both the scientific and practitioner components of intervention.

Good for students interested in: psychological intervention, intervention theory, outcome evaluation, clinical practice, therapeutic techniques, evidence-based practice, psychological assessment, treatment planning

metadata.prerequisites_raw: PSYC 201 and 241.

courses.title: Human Neuropsychology
courses.document:
PSYC 387 - Human Neuropsychology
Department: PSYC | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: PSYC 201, 221, and 280.

Examines the neural processes that underlie cognitive functioning and behaviour. Topics include neuroanatomy, neuropathology, brain damage, neurological diseases (e.g., schizophrenia, Alzheimer's, Parkinson's), and problems in spatial ability, memory, language, mood and anxiety.

Good for students interested in: neuroanatomy, neuropathology, cognitive functioning, brain damage, neurological diseases, memory, language, mood disorders

courses.title: Biolog.Rhythms/Sleep
courses.document:
PSYC 388 - Biolog.Rhythms/Sleep
Department: PSYC | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: PSYC 201 and 280.

Behaviour and physiology are regulated by biological clocks, which function to synchronize the organism optimally with its environment. In this course we examine the adaptive role of clocks in animal behaviour, the neural and endocrine mechanisms of daily, monthly and yearly rhythms, and the relevance of clocks, rhythms and sleep to human performance and psychopathology. We will also consider the mechanisms and functions of sleep states.

Good for students interested in: biological rhythms, circadian clocks, sleep physiology, neural mechanisms, endocrine regulation, animal behavior, human performance, psychopathology

metadata.prerequisites_raw: PSYC 201 and 280.

courses.title: Selected Topics in Psychology

PSYC 391 - Selected Topics in Psychology
Department: PSYC | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: PSYC 201. Other prerequisites vary by topic offering.

Course can be repeated for credit.

Good for students interested in: psychological theories, research methods, cognitive processes, behavioral analysis, statistical data interpretation, experimental design, critical thinking, neuropsychology

metadata.prerequisites_raw: PSYC 201. Other prerequisites vary by topic offering.

courses.title: Microbiology

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: BISC 102, MBB 222, and MBB 231, all with a minimum grade of C-.

A broad introduction to micro-organisms (bacteria, viruses and archaea) with an emphasis on their molecular biology, metabolism, physiology, and interactions with their hosts and environment. Labs introduce students to modern microbial techniques.

Good for students interested in: microbiology, molecular biology, microbial metabolism, microbial physiology, host-microbe interactions, microbial ecology, laboratory techniques, microbial genetics

metadata.prerequisites_raw: (BISC 205 or BPK 205) and MBB 231, both with a minimum grade of C-.

courses.title: Vertebrate Biology

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: BISC 101 and 102, both with a minimum grade of C-.

An overview of the evolution and diversity of vertebrates, with an emphasis on the evolutionary innovations and characteristics that led to this diversity. Labs explore comparative anatomy through dissections, bones, and other specimens.

Good for students interested in: vertebrate evolution, comparative anatomy, evolutionary innovations, vertebrate diversity, dissection techniques, skeletal biology, functional morphology, phylogenetics

metadata.prerequisites_raw: BISC 101 and 102, both with a minimum grade of C-.

courses.title: Functional Anatomy
courses.document:
BPK 326 - Functional Anatomy
Department: BPK | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: Admission to the major or honours program in Behavioural Neuroscience or Biomedical Physiology or Kinesiology. BPK 142, 201, 205 and at least 60 units. Behavioral Neuroscience Major and Honours studen...

A detailed study of human anatomy with emphasis on clinically relevant applications in health, injury and disease. Virtual cadaver dissection, comparative laboratory work, and an introduction to medical imaging emphasize the layered, three-dimensional organization of the human body. Participation in all labs is required.

Good for students interested in: human anatomy, clinical applications, injury analysis, disease mechanisms, virtual cadaver dissection, medical imaging, comparative anatomy, three-dimensional body organization

metadata.prerequisites_raw: Admission to the major or honours program in Behavioural Neuroscience or Biomedical Physiology or Kinesiology. BPK 142, 201, 205 and at least 60 units. Behavioral Neuroscience Major and Honours students require BPK 142, 205, PSYC 280 and at least 60 units.

courses.title: Active Health
courses.document:
BPK 340 - Active Health
Department: BPK | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: BPK 142, STAT 201 (or PSYC 201). Recommended: BPK 140.

Relationships among health, physical activity, and other health-associated behaviors are examined. In addition, the theories and models of health behavior, in the context of intervention and promotion strategies, are discussed. Pertinent background information is provided, concerning the influence of fitness on various disease states, as well as the epidemiology of health and exercise behaviors.

Good for students interested in: health behavior theories, physical activity, health promotion, intervention strategies, fitness and disease, epidemiology of exercise, health-associated behaviors, behavior change models

metadata.prerequisites_raw: BPK 142, STAT 201 (or PSYC 201). Recommended: BPK 140.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: None | Prerequisites: BPK 105 or 205, and 142.

The fundamentals of physiological growth and development from conception to maturity. Topics included form a strong foundation for those interested in designing appropriate activity programs for children of all ages.

metadata.prerequisites_raw: BPK 105 or 205, and 142.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: This course is only open to students admitted to the business administration minor between Fall 2012 - Summer 2016 and who have credit for BUS 251 with a minimum grade of C- and 45 units, OR to studen...

In-depth coverage of accounting, methods, problems, and limitations, associated with liabilities and owners' equity.

metadata.prerequisites_raw: BUS 320 with a minimum grade of C-; 45 units.

BUS 331 - Corporate Taxation

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: BUS 330 (or BUS 329) with a minimum grade of C-, 45 units.

Students will examine the taxation of corporations, corporate distributions, and transactions between corporations and their shareholders. Topics include an in-depth coverage of taxable capital gains; deferred income plans; and the taxation of corporate entities, partnerships, trusts and corporate reorganizations.

courses.title: International Bus. Strategy
courses.document:
BUS 340 - International Bus. Strategy
Department: BUS | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: This course is only open to students admitted to the business administration minor between Fall 2012 - Summer 2016 and who have 45 units, OR to students admitted to the business administration minor F...

Identifies how Multinational Enterprises (MNEs) formulate strategies and what organizational capabilities are needed to support these strategies in order to produce international competitive advantages. Students will study the criteria for assessing strategic and organizational capabilities of MNEs to determine solutions for increasing organizational performance.

Good for students interested in: international business strategy, multinational enterprises, organizational capabilities, competitive advantage, strategic management, global market analysis, performance assessment, strategic decision-making
