Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: This course is only open to students admitted to the business administration minor between Fall 2012 - Summer 2016 and who have 45 units, OR to students admitted to the business administration minor F...

Provides an introduction to the field and practice of marketing. Takes an expansive approach and addresses how people, ideas, organizations, and places, as well as more conventional products/services, are marketed. The course goes beyond theory and challenges students to apply these concepts to real world situations.

Good for students interested in: marketing principles, consumer behavior, market segmentation, branding strategies, marketing research, promotional tactics, strategic marketing, real-world application

courses.document:
BUS 347 - Consumer Behaviour

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: BUS 343 with a minimum grade of C- and 45 units; OR business administration minor students admitted Fall 2025 - onwards with BUS 341 with a minimum grade of C- and 45 units.

courses.title: Topics: Comm Policy

CMNS 312 - Topics: Comm Policy
Department: CMNS | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: 17 CMNS units with a minimum grade of C- or 45 units with a minimum CGPA of 2.00.

Topics cover a range of policy and governance concerns and processes pertaining to communication, media, and/or culture in national and international contexts. Topics vary and include: content regulation, copyright, media institutions, media advocacy, and different perspectives to study these issues. This course can be repeated twice for credit if the topics are different (up to a maximum of three times).

Good for students interested in: communication policy, media governance, content regulation, copyright law, media institutions, media advocacy, cultural policy, policy analysis

metadata.prerequisites_raw: 17 CMNS units with a minimum grade of C- or 45 units with a minimum CGPA of 2.00.

courses.title: Topics: Data and Society
courses.document:
CMNS 313 - Topics: Data and Society
Department: CMNS | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Harbour Ctr | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: 17 CMNS units with a minimum grade of C- or 45 units with a minimum CGPA of 2.00.

Topics in the social, political, and cultural aspects of data and datafication. Explores social and philosophical implications of gathering, interpreting, and managing data. Topics include: data protection, visualization or sonification, data activism, big data, algorithmic bias and decision making, AI harms, big data, and the political economy of data. This course can be repeated twice for credit if the topics are different (up to a maximum of three times).

Good for students interested in: data protection, data visualization, algorithmic bias, ai ethics, big data, data activism, political economy of data, data interpretation

metadata.prerequisites_raw: 17 CMNS units with a minimum grade of C- or 45 units with a minimum CGPA of 2.00.

Department: CMNS | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Blended
WQB: None | Prerequisites: 17 CMNS units with a minimum grade of C- or 45 units with a minimum CGPA of 2.00.

Examination of the emergence and shaping of information and communication technologies and science in the digital age. Explores new media and social change between everyday life, social institutions, and various enterprises. Emphasis is placed on social context and relations of power. This course can be repeated twice for credit if the topics are different (up to a maximum of three times).

Good for students interested in: information and communication technologies, digital media, social change, science and technology studies, social institutions, power relations, new media, social context

metadata.prerequisites_raw: 17 CMNS units with a minimum grade of C- or 45 units with a minimum CGPA of 2.00.

courses.title: Intermediate Macroecon.Theory
courses.document:
ECON 305 - Intermediate Macroecon.Theory
Department: ECON | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: ECON 201 with a minimum grade of C-; 45 units. Students with a minimum grade of A- in ECON 103 and 105 at Simon Fraser University at their first attempt can complete ECON 305 concurrently with ECON 20...

Concepts and methods of analysis of macroeconomic variables -- consumption, investment, government and foreign trade. Classical and Keynesian models compared; analysis of economic statics and dynamics.

courses.title: Language Acquisition

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: None | Prerequisites: EDUC 220 or PSYC 250 or LING 100. Students may be required to successfully complete a Criminal Record Check.

A review of theories of language acquisition and their relationship to child communication disorders. Good for students interested in: language acquisition, child communication disorders, developmental language differences, autism spectrum disorder, sensory disabilities, emotional and behavioral disabilities, interdisciplinary early intervention, language structure and use

metadata.prerequisites_raw: EDUC 220 or PSYC 250 or LING 100. Students may be required to successfully complete a Criminal Record Check.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: At least 45 units, including GEOG 100 or REM 100.

Factors underlying the changing geography of tourism. Issues of demand, supply and impact are examined.

metadata.prerequisites_raw: At least 45 units, including GEOG 100 or REM 100.

Campus: Harbour Ctr | Delivery: Blended
WQB: None | Prerequisites: At least 45 units, including GEOG 100.

An introduction to the major approaches and key ideas of the professions of urban governance; urban planning and urban policy. metadata.prerequisites_raw: At least 45 units, including GEOG 100.

Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: 45 units. Recommended: HSCI 130.

New formations of wealth and power that contribute to international health disparities and consideration of the relations of power both between and within nation-states that make some people sick and keep others well. metadata.prerequisites_raw: 45 units. Recommended: HSCI 130.

WQB: None | Prerequisites: Completion of Certificate in Indigenous Language Proficiency; or with permission of instructor.

Students may retake this course with focus on a different Indigenous language.

Good for students interested in: indigenous languages, conversational fluency, narrative proficiency, oral communication, written communication, traditional knowledge, language immersion, language skills development

metadata.prerequisites_raw: Completion of Certificate in Indigenous Language Proficiency; or with permission of instructor.

courses.title: INLG Immersion III
courses.document:
INLG 358 - INLG Immersion III
Department: INLG | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Off-campus | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: Completion of Certificate in Indigenous Language Proficiency including INLG (or FNLG) 258; or permission of instructor.

Intensive immersion "on the land" or in a classroom setting led by elder or fluent speaker in an Indigenous language at an intermediate level. Exposes learners to a variety of authentic situations where the language is used and spoken in everyday tasks. May be taken again when offered in another Indigenous language set of courses.

Good for students interested in: indigenous languages, language immersion, conversational fluency, cultural context, authentic communication, listening comprehension, language revitalization, intermediate language skills

metadata.prerequisites_raw: Completion of Certificate in Indigenous Language Proficiency including INLG (or FNLG) 258; or permission of instructor.

courses.title: Phonology
courses.document:
LING 321 - Phonology
Department: LING | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Blended
WQB: None | Prerequisites: LING 220.

An overview of theoretical principles in phonology.

Good for students interested in: phonological theory, sound patterns, distinctive features, phonemes, syllable structure, phonological rules, linguistic analysis, speech sounds

metadata.prerequisites_raw: LING 220.

courses.title: Syntax
courses.document:
LING 322 - Syntax
Department: LING | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Blended
WQB: None | Prerequisites: LING 220.

Introduces theories of sentence structure.

Good for students interested in: syntax, sentence structure, generative grammar, phrase structure rules, constituency, syntactic trees, transformational grammar, linguistic analysis

metadata.prerequisites_raw: LING 220.

courses.title: Introductory Immunology
courses.document:
MBB 326 - Introductory Immunology
Department: MBB | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: MBB 231 with a minimum grade of C.

Introduction to the structure and function of the immune system and how this system protects against microbial infections. Innate immune responses, including the function of innate immune cells, receptors and complement. Adaptive immune responses, including the organization of lymphoid organs, development and function of T and B cells, and antibodies.

Good for students interested in: immune system, innate immunity, adaptive immunity, t cells, b cells, antibodies, lymphoid organs, immune response mechanisms

metadata.prerequisites_raw: MBB 231 with a minimum grade of C.

courses.title: Politics Across the Pacific
courses.document:
POL 341 - Politics Across the Pacific
Department: POL | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Blended
WQB: None | Prerequisites: POL 141 and three lower division units in political science or permission of the department.

Focuses on the evolution of political relation between East Asia and Canada since the mid-19th century to the contemporary period. It covers diplomatic/military and socio-economic and cultural relations, sometimes cutting across national and sub-national boundaries. Utilizes various theoretical and analytical perspectives from political science and other disciplines to assess the importance and causes of key events.

Good for students interested in: east asian politics, canada-pacific relations, diplomatic history, socio-economic relations, political theory, international relations, cross-cultural analysis, political evolution

metadata.prerequisites_raw: POL 141 and three lower division units in political science or permission of the department.

courses.title: Environmental and Planning Law
courses.document:
REM 319 - Environmental and Planning Law
Department: REM | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: 45 units.

Provides a practical introduction to the legal system governing the use and protection of the environment and planning and land use law in Canada. A central theme is the difference between the law on paper and the law in practice.

Good for students interested in: environmental law, planning law, land use regulation, legal frameworks, environmental protection, regulatory compliance, policy analysis, legal interpretation

metadata.prerequisites_raw: 45 units.

courses.title: Sexuality and Society
courses.document:
SA 337 - Sexuality and Society
Department: SA | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: Online
WQB: None | Prerequisites: SA 101 or 150 or 201W.

The categories that organize our understandings of sex, gender and sexuality have powerful histories and roles in organizing social relations in western society. Social activists and academics contest the naturalness of these categories, particularly that of the binary opposition between male and female, and related assumptions about sexuality and sexual orientation. This course encompasses a range of perspectives on sex/gender identity, sexuality, and the relationship between the two. These perspectives include feminist, lesbian and gay, and queer and transgender challenges to traditional understandings of sex/gender identity and sexuality.

Good for students interested in: sex and gender theory, sexuality studies, feminist theory, queer theory, transgender studies, social constructionism, sexual orientation, gender identity

metadata.prerequisites_raw: SA 101 or 150 or 201W.

courses.title: The Business of Engineering
courses.document:
SEE 300 - The Business of Engineering
Department: SEE | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: A minimum of 65 units OR a minimum of 55 units plus two-term co-op work.

Economic and entrepreneurial concepts important to engineers who manage projects, run businesses, or need to decide on the most efficient method for accomplishing a task. Topics include: financial accounting and metrics, economic equivalence, rates of return, depreciation, income taxes, project and cost-benefit analyses, capital budgeting, financing methods, risk and uncertainty, business plans.

Good for students interested in: financial accounting, economic equivalence, project analysis, cost-benefit analysis, capital budgeting, risk management, business planning, depreciation

metadata.prerequisites_raw: A minimum of 65 units OR a minimum of 55 units plus two-term co-op work.

courses.title: Integrated Energy Solution II
courses.document:
SEE 310 - Integrated Energy Solution II
Department: SEE | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: Completion of one co-op work term; SEE 111, 224, 242, 251.

Integrated design methodology for sustainable engineering problems; implementation through an energy system project undertaken in a project based learning environment. Introduction to modelling, simulation and optimization of energy systems. Global and local regulatory and policy frameworks. Demonstration of integrated sustainability thinking through design project, report and presentation. Special emphasis on communication skills.

Good for students interested in: sustainable engineering, energy system modeling, simulation, optimization, integrated design methodology, regulatory frameworks, policy analysis, communication skills

metadata.prerequisites_raw: Completion of one co-op work term; SEE 111, 224, 242, 251.

courses.title: Heat & Mass Transfer
courses.document:
SEE 324 - Heat & Mass Transfer
Department: SEE | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: PHYS 141, SEE 224, SEE 225.

Provides the basic principles of heat and mass transfer with analysis and application to real-world sustainable energy systems. Governing relationships for conduction, free and forced convection, and radiation will be explained and then applied to solve practical problems. Practical application of theory (e.g. heat exchanger design) will be introduced.

Good for students interested in: heat transfer, mass transfer, conduction, convection, radiation, heat exchanger design, sustainable energy systems, thermal analysis

metadata.prerequisites_raw: PHYS 141, SEE 224, SEE 225.

courses.title: Power Electronics
courses.document:
SEE 331 - Power Electronics
Department: SEE | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: SEE 231 and SEE 251.

Introduction to the fundamentals of power electronic circuits, components, and operation, and principles of electric power conversion in DC and AC applications.

Good for students interested in: power electronic circuits, electric power conversion, dc applications, ac applications, semiconductor devices, circuit design, energy conversion, switching techniques

metadata.prerequisites_raw: SEE 231 and SEE 251.

courses.title: Signals and Systems
courses.document:
SEE 341 - Signals and Systems
Department: SEE | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: SEE 242, SEE 230.

Modelling and analysis of continuous and discrete signals using linear techniques. Laplace transforms; methods for basic modelling of physical systems; discrete and continuous convolution; impulse and step response; transfer functions and filtering; continuous Fourier transform and its relationship to the Laplace transform; frequency response and Bode plots; sampling; Z-transform.

Good for students interested in: signals and systems, laplace transform, fourier transform, convolution, transfer functions, frequency response, sampling, z-transform

metadata.prerequisites_raw: SEE 242, SEE 230.

courses.title: Feedback Control Systems
courses.document:
SEE 342 - Feedback Control Systems
Department: SEE | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: SEE 341.

Fundamentals of feedback control system design and analysis, including practical and theoretical aspects. Significant lab component in which students design controllers and evaluate their robustness to modeling errors and nonlinearities.

Good for students interested in: feedback control systems, controller design, system analysis, robustness evaluation, modeling errors, nonlinear systems, control theory, laboratory experimentation

metadata.prerequisites_raw: SEE 341.

courses.title: App Thermo & Energy Conversion
courses.document:
SEE 352 - App Thermo & Energy Conversion
Department: SEE | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: SEE 224.

Application of thermodynamics, chemistry, and transport physics to energy conversion technologies and systems. Analysis of energy conversion systems with emphasis on efficiency, performance, and environmental impact.

Good for students interested in: thermodynamics, energy conversion, transport physics, chemistry, system efficiency, performance analysis, environmental impact, energy systems

metadata.prerequisites_raw: SEE 224.

courses.title: Energy Storage
courses.document:
SEE 354 - Energy Storage
Department: SEE | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Surrey | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: SEE 222, SEE 331, SEE 324.

The characteristics, applications, limitations, and environmental impacts of various energy storage technologies and techniques are analyzed, compared and implemented in a lab setting. Electrochemical, mechanical, thermal and emerging energy storage options are considered.

Good for students interested in: energy storage technologies, electrochemical storage, mechanical energy storage, thermal energy storage, environmental impacts, energy storage applications, lab implementation, technology comparison

metadata.prerequisites_raw: SEE 222, SEE 331, SEE 324.

courses.title: Industrial Internship II
courses.document:
SEE 390 - Industrial Internship II
Department: SEE | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Off-campus, Other Vancouver | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: SEE 290 or SEE 294.

The second of 3 term-long work placements in which students gain real-world experience in research or industrial facilities, often designing and building real products. Students integrate theory and practice as a student engineer. Students are supported to prepare their job search strategies, conduct professional interviews and explore and develop their career goals. Units from this course do not count towards the units required for an SFU degree.

Good for students interested in: workplace integration, engineering design, product development, professional communication, job search strategies, interview skills, career planning, practical engineering experience

metadata.prerequisites_raw: SEE 290 or SEE 294.

courses.title: Special Internship II
courses.document:
SEE 394 - Special Internship II
Department: SEE | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Off-campus, Other Vancouver | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: SEE 290 or SEE 294.

An alternative experience to a regular co-op work term. This may include, but is not restricted to, a self-directed project (eg. sustainable community project), service (eg. intern with Engineers Without Borders), entrepreneurial, or research terms. Prior approval of the Internship Coordinator is required. To be granted credit Special Internship II must meet the regular criteria for a co-op work term. Units from this course do not count towards the units required for an SFU degree.

Good for students interested in: project management, sustainable development, research methods, community engagement, entrepreneurial skills, self-directed learning, service learning, engineering applications

metadata.prerequisites_raw: SEE 290 or SEE 294.

courses.title: Corporate Finance
courses.document:
BUS 313 - Corporate Finance
Department: BUS | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: BUS 312, BUS 207 or ECON 201, all with a minimum grade of C- and 45 units.

Corporate financial management decisions and valuation methods. Topics include investment decisions, financing decisions, capital structure policy, payout policy, and valuation of investment projects and firms.

Good for students interested in: corporate financial management, investment decisions, financing decisions, capital structure, payout policy, project valuation, firm valuation, financial decision-making

metadata.prerequisites_raw: BUS 312, BUS 207 or ECON 201, all with a minimum grade of C- and 45 units.

courses.title: Marketing Research
courses.document:
BUS 345 - Marketing Research
Department: BUS | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: BUS 232 or ECON 233 or STAT 270 or STAT 271, and BUS 343, both with a minimum grade of C- and 45 units; OR data science majors with BUS 343 with a minimum grade of C- and 45 units.

A course in the management of marketing research. The basics of the design, conduct, and analysis of marketing research studies.

Good for students interested in: marketing research, research design, data analysis, survey methods, consumer behavior, statistical techniques, data interpretation, market segmentation

metadata.prerequisites_raw: BUS 232 or ECON 233 or STAT 270 or STAT 271, and BUS 343, both with a minimum grade of C- and 45 units; OR data science majors with BUS 343 with a minimum grade of C- and 45 units.

courses.title: Project Management
courses.document:
BUS 361 - Project Management
Department: BUS | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: 45 units OR business administration minor students admitted Fall 2025 - onwards with 45 units.

Introduction to the hard and soft skills of project management. Management software and techniques such as work breakdown, estimation, budgeting and status reporting are used. Applies structured processes and develops team-based skills and knowledge. Assumes no prior computing or technical knowledge.

Good for students interested in: project management, work breakdown structure, estimation techniques, budgeting, status reporting, team collaboration, management software, structured processes

metadata.prerequisites_raw: 45 units OR business administration minor students admitted Fall 2025 - onwards with 45 units.

courses.title: Business Process Analysis
courses.document:
BUS 362 - Business Process Analysis
Department: BUS | Level: 300 | Units: 4
Campus: Burnaby | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: BUS 237 with a minimum grade of C-; 45 units; OR Data Science majors with 45 units.

Prepares students to model, analyze and propose improvements to business processes. In the major project, students analyze a process within an organization and use current techniques and tools to propose changes and a supporting information system.

Good for students interested in: business process modeling, process analysis, process improvement, information systems, organizational analysis, data-driven decision making, workflow optimization, systems thinking

metadata.prerequisites_raw: BUS 237 with a minimum grade of C-; 45 units; OR Data Science majors with 45 units.

courses.title: Professional Practices
courses.document:
CA 304 - Professional Practices
Department: CA | Level: 300 | Units: 3
Campus: Harbour Ctr | Delivery: In Person
WQB: None | Prerequisites: 30 units in Contemporary Arts.

Focus on understanding working life in the arts and culture sector as related to students own creative and scholarly practices. Prepares students for internships and practicums by building knowledge of potential working environments and approaches. Additional topics include career and job search as well as development of artistic projects.

Good for students interested in: arts management, cultural sector, professional development, career planning, internship preparation, project management, creative practices, job search strategies

metadata.prerequisites_raw: 30 units in Contemporary Arts.
